Body Snippet: Lucas and Megan, We couldn't have had a better time with you guys either. Such a great night- hope we can top it next time. I'll start working on adding more mixology recipes to my arsenal for
Email RTF:
Lucas and Megan,

We couldn't have had a better time with you guys either. Such a great night-

hope we can top it next time. I'll start working on adding more mixology recipes

to my arsenal for next time haha. Glad you enjoyed it.

I came away feeling very encouraged about this dream of a blunt neckline shaped

clothing line. I know that based on my experiences with Magnetie, that far more

important than anything else, to be successful you must surround yourself with

people on your team who 1- believe in the vision, 2- motivate you to be better,

and 3- can do what they do best better than you can. For these reasons I feel

like having you (and Megan having our backs in the background) on our team would

be a huge advantage. The next step is to set up a meeting with Joe to go through

the rest- this week preferably. I wonder if we can have a call tomorrow night at

630pm? Would that work for you? Adding Joe to this string- Joe does that work

for you too? Then we can chat about what the common interests are and formalize

a plan of attack.

Looking forward to many more nights like we had - if not with Blunt Neck

business as the focus but just in general as friends as well.

Joel Paglione/ Honorary Mixologist

630-360-0026

www.joelpaglione.com

Name: awa-blunt-130
Subject: Blunt Neck Mailer Tube Concept
Body Snippet: Guys, Check out this concept I put together for the mailing tube. It requires no special printing on the tube if we can just source a black paper tube and cut on an angle both sides then just use thick
Email RTF:
Guys,

Check out this concept I put together for the mailing tube. It requires no

special printing on the tube if we can just source a black paper tube and cut on

an angle both sides then just use thick white paper table to cover the seem

between the top portion and the bottom portion it will look like our logo. Then

the customer "Cracks" or "Breaks" the two ends at the paper seem to access the

goods inside. The goods inside would be inside another internal tube that would

add rigidity and protection as well as act as the brace between the bottom and

top lid. We could also go white tube, black tape but I think the black then

white would be more appealing and get less dirty. But then again white from/to

stickers may uglify this thing if black.

Found them at this link but im sure we can source in usa. I will make a demo of

this tomorrow using a tube I bought at staples.

http://www.alibaba.com/product-gs/535460206/round_paper_postal_tubes_black_paper.html

Cool?
Attachments: 2014-01-20T02-42 [joel.paglione@gmail.com] Blunt Neck Mailer Tube Concept - BluntNeckMailerTubeDesign_Slide1.bmp

Email RTF:
I can explain the tube progress at our meeting on Wednesday night if we have it.

I don't mind paper padded envelopes but when they get wet during transportation

they look like crap when they're white. But it may be the quickest cheapest way

to go about. Otherwise yes printing on padded white envelopes from tables may

be the fastest way to go versus having to order paper padded white envelopes

online. We can talk about this on Wednesday. As far as the printing on the

neckline prior to production, it just was not possible to coordinate it this

time but what I have instructed stock to do is use black fabric on the bottom of

the neckline for the white shirts and white fabric on the bottom of the neckline

for blackshirts simulating the same thing using fabric colors all we would then

need to do is add a small/in the reverse color on the neckline via a template

process and taping and masking. Maybe we can investigate this Lucas? Can we use

tinted discharge or order based Inc. to add the small/. I am thinking since the

small/is so small we should not be as concerned about if there's any potential

overspray or bleeding or whatever you would call that. It should be less risky

than doing the whole logo for looking like crap. Thoughts? We can again talk

about this on Wednesday.

​

Name: awa-blunt-190
Subject: Blunt Neck Production (Batch 144 Mens Short Sleeve Shirts) Issues
Email in PDF text: /Emails/All/2014-02-18-Blunt Neck Production (Batch 144 Mens Short Sleeve Shirts) Issues.pdf
Body Snippet: Tim, As promised, attached is a document describing the issues we are seeing with the shirts. Please advise how we move forward. I would like to discuss next steps on a conference call with all parties
Email RTF:
Tim,

​

As promised, attached is a document describing the issues we are seeing with the

shirts. Please advise how we move forward. I would like to discuss next steps on

a conference call with all parties involved, ie Stock and Blunt Neck. I can

arrange that conference call if you advise when you and your team would

be available. We are currently holding our printing in order to hear back on

your proposed resolution but cannot wait too long, as you are aware, the delays

is mistakes with material arrival have already put us weeks behind our planned

launch date for our clothing line (ie Valentines Day).

​

I want to end this note by saying that we mean not to come off as being

"difficult to work with". We recognize that not only you personally but your

entire team has been very kind, courteous, professional, easy to deal with and

responsive thus far and we know you have gone out of your way to try and help

make Blunt Neck successful. We want a long business relationship with Stock.

When my friend Ryan Beshel suggested you guys were the best, we know he was

right and we still do feel you are one of the best manufacturers around. We just

need to dial in these processes and do whats right to improve the issues

identified in the attached. I recognize, starting a clothing line is not easy,

it doesn't always work out perfectly to plan, and it can't always be perfect, or

else everyone would be doing it. But I know that these issues are things I know

you wouldn't let ship out of your factory if they were your clothes either

without doing everything possible to find an interim containment and permanent

fix for. I appreciate your help in advance resolving these issues.

​

Let me know your thoughts asap.

​

Respectfully,

​

Joel Paglione

630-360-0026

​

------ Attachment Summary of Issues Identified 02.18.2014.pdf -----

        Summary of Issues Identified

1. Loose, sloppy, and hanging stitches on bottom

 hem, and sleeve hems. Additional Info: All shirts have this issue, not specific to a certain size/color. Some are worse than others but they all look as though the shirt could come apart. In one instance already, the sleeve stitching has come loose and opened up after first wash Additional Background of the Issue: Our request was “blind serge stitching” so that the sleeves and bottom of shirt do not have obvious hems and instead the customers visual focus would be drawn towards the blunt shaped neckline. The discussion had between Tim and I was that “the structural integrity of that stitch” would not be great if we used a blind serge stitch. My interpretation was that by “Structural Integrity” we were implying that over time the hem would not be as structurally sound to withstand repeated use/washes etc. not that the shirts hems would come out of production sloppy, loose and coming apart even prior to its first wash cycle. If that was the case, obviously we wouldn’t advise to move forward with that stitch. Impacts: The impacts are two fold: 1/ customer dissatisfaction of perceived quality of the made in USA shirts; and 2/ the likelihood of the stitches coming apart and potential for returns of sold units. Courses of Action Options: 1/ rerun production with better controls on stitching. 2/ rerun production with a different stitch type if this result cannot be controlled (against our intended design spec). Or 3/ Do nothing and improve next run. Summary of Issues Identified

1.

​

  As can be seen above, loose hanging         threads not trimmed. Summary of Issues Identified

1.

​

  As can be seen above, loose stitching   coming apart, and hanging threads                 uncut. Summary of Issues Identified

1.

​

   As can be seen above, threads so loose a   index finger could go through the stitch                    loops.       Summary of Issues Identified

2. Material ripping at neckline seam.

 Additional Info: All shirts have this issue, not specific to a certain size/color but worse on white. Some are worse than others but they all exhibit holes at neckline prior to washing and worsen after first wash cycle. Additional Background of the Issue: Our request was to use dense/heavy enough bamboo (rayon) material to be durable but also extremely soft. This was not a simple request we understand because they both contradict each other. Regardless, this is going to be obviously unacceptable to the customers to have rips appearing prior and after one wash cycle. Impacts: The impact is customer dissatisfaction and high potential for returns of sold units. Courses of Action Options: 1/ rerun production with thicker heavier bamboo (rayon) material. 2/ rerun production with a different stitch type along neckline to add structural reinforcement and integrity to the neckline. Or 3/ Take back all the shirts, and reprocess them with an additional stitch under the current neckline stitch that looks exactly similar to the Yellow Shirt in next slides to add additional structural integrity (if the experts agree this would add strength to the neckline where it is currently ripping). Summary of Issues Identified

2.

​

    As can be seen above, after 1 wash very obvious holes  appearing at neckline and shirt is deformed after one wash   (deformation probably due to the fabric weight/density) Summary of Issues Identified

2.

​

  As can be seen above, hole is also appearing         at neckline of the black shirts Summary of Issues Identified

2.

​

   Proposed potential solution, reprocessing the shirts and reinforcing the  neckline with an additional stitch on neckline. We would like to show you   this shirt to better show you what we are suggesting. Again, we are not  the experts however and are not sure if a) this is possible to do after the           fact, and b) if it will help with the ripping that is occuring.

​

Name: awa-blunt-191
Subject: Re: Blunt Neck Production (Batch 144 Mens Short Sleeve Shirts) Issues
Email in PDF text: /Emails/All/2014-02-19-Re: Blunt Neck Production (Batch 144 Mens Short Sleeve Shirts) Issues.pdf
Body Snippet: Joel- Thanks for your e-mail and the organized summary of issues document. It looks like the issues all come down to the stitch type and a weak point at the corners of the "blunt neck". As
Email RTF:
EMAIL SUBJECT: Re: Blunt Neck Production (Batch 144 Mens Short Sleeve Shirts) Issues​Joel-​Thanks for your e-mail and the organized summary of issues document. Itlooks like the issues all come down to the stitch type and a weak point atthe corners of the "blunt neck".​As for the stitch, I suggested several times that you use a cover stitch(what we use on all Stock knits) rather than the blind stitch duringsampling and prior to production. You insisted that you needed the blindstitch aesthetic because it appears on all your "high end" t-shirts. It'sa weaker stitch and has a loose appearance, but we made a sample and yousaid it was perfect, so that's the stitch we used on the first productionrun.​Attached is a picture of the sample you approved (on the left) and thecover stitch we use on all of own knits (on the right). You'll notice thatthe stitch is looser and has loose threads. I came in on my day off lastSaturday to QC your shirts because I knew you needed them asap. I madesure they looked like the sample you approved before handing them off toyou. If I had clipped every single thread, it would've taken much longerthan the 5 hours I spent on them and would increase the cost of thegarments in the future as more time is needed from the operators to clipevery single hanging thread.​The cover stitch is a cleaner and stronger stitch that requires much lessattention on the QC end- there's really no reason not to use it. Iunderstand you want the invisible stitch on the exterior of the garment,but the only way we can achieve that is by having a loose/weak stitch onthe inside. I went out of my way a few months ago to do research on themachinery or attachment required to make the blind stitch for you. I wentto three separate shops in Chicago including Goldblatt's Sewing Machines inWicker Park with 50 years of experience, and they had no idea, so we askedJUKI- the premier Japanese sewing machine company and they had no ideaeither. This, to me, means that it's not a very common stitch anddefinitely not a high-end one.​It's possible that the ripping on the corners of the blunt neck is due tothe fabric, but I think the solution is a different finish or edge stitcharound the neckline, similar to the yellow shirt image you sent over (whichis a cover stitch). The yellow shirt is also a much thicker durablefabric- looks like 100% cotton. You don't see t-shirts with corners like ablunt neck- one reason could be that it creates a weak stress point. I didthe best I could sourcing what you wanted: something strong, thin, opaque,and bamboo. All of our other customers source their own fabric, but youexpressed no interest in doing so, so it was up to me to find what Ithought would fit the description of what you wanted. You initially wanted100% bamboo, but that doesn't exist so I sourced the highest content ofbamboo available as all bamboo fabrics are cotton blends. There's no way Icould have foretold that the fabric would be weak at the corners of theshirt, as we've never made a blunt neck shirt before.​I know you have a very impressive resume when it comes to manufacturingarmored vehicles, but unfortunately that doesn't translate into the garmentindustry. All of our other customers provide tech packs, samples, sourcetheir own fabrics and trims, etc. They've gone to school for clothingdesign, have years of experience, and a fundamental understanding of fabricproperties, stitch types, finishes, etc. They know their product inside andout prior to coming to us for production. When we take on a project fromthe ground up, there are going to be speed bumps and things will arise thatare out of our control. I know it's seemingly a simple t-shirt, but thecombination of very specific features you'd like without a generalknowledge of apparel is problematic. I did my best to guide you, but to behonest you're not the easiest person to convince. That said, we'll do ourbest to remedy the situation and create a product you can stand behind. Wepride ourselves on our craftsmanship and do our best to meet the needs ofall our clients.​With the shirts you have, we can try to take one apart at the hems (seamrip) and redo it with the cover stitch. If that works out, we can redo allthe shirts that way and just charge hourly for labor. As for the cornersripping, it's not the stitch, it's the fabric- so you might consider movingaway from bamboo and using cotton. Also, if you were able to get samplesyou were happy with from China and the price is right- that might be thebest play in this scenario. Made in USA is definitely a selling point, butit has to make sense on the business end.​Let me know your thoughts,​Tim​On Tue, Feb 18, 2014 at 7:17 PM, Lucas Guariglia<lucas@rowboatcreative.com>wrote:​> Perfect joel. Great rebuttal. Thanks for the time involved here.>> Lucas Guariglia> Rowboat Creative> 847.828.0944 c> 773.675.BOAT (2628) o>> Sent from my iPhone>>>> > On Feb 18, 2014, at 6:37 PM, Joel Paglione <joel.paglione@gmail.com>> wrote:> >> > Tim,> >> > As promised, attached is a document describing the issues we are seeing> with the shirts. Subject: Blunt Neck Clothing, Re-Sourcing
Body Snippet: Ben, Thanks again for the conversation today over the phone and your offer to put me in touch with someone your trust and work within the industry. Just a quick background on the situation. As you know
Email RTF:
Ben,​Thanks again for the conversation today over the phone and your offer to put mein touch with someone your trust and work within the industry. Just a quickbackground on the situation. As you know, my partners and I are working onreleasing to market a new alternative to the common crew and v-neck necklinedesign called the “Blunt Neck”. Eventually we are planning to create multipleSKUs in both Women’s wear (tank tops, shirt dresses, bathing suits, tees, croptops, racerback performance apparel, etc) and Men’s wear but initially we arefocused on launching our a Basic Men’s Short Sleeve T-Shirt in our “Blunt Neck”neckline design. My mandate I set forth was to look for a soft but durableunique luxury fabric like Modal or Bamboo (rayon) for our first run and I wantedthe shirts to be made with “Blind Serge Stitching” because I wanted the hems notto take away from the unique neckline design. My other big push was “Made inUSA” and if we could help it “Made in Chicago” locally. So we worked with localfashion contacts to point us in the right direction and landed on a companycalled “Stock Manufacturing Co.” (www.stockmfg.co) . They helped us developphysical patterns for our Men’s Tee in sizes S, M, L and XL which we still ownand have access to. Once we samples we kicked off production with them for ourfirst 144 shirts with 6 colors (White, Black, Smoke, Navy Blue, Brick, and BabyBlue) and in 4 sizes (S, M , L, and XL). Since we are not familiar with fabricsourcing we asked them also to source the bamboo fabric they would recommend.Fast forward to today, we have received our first round of 144 units and theyare terribly made. The hem stitching on the bottom of the shirts and the armslooks like it is falling apart and very sloppy (as seen in attached presentationitem 1). The worst part is that the material they sourced alone with the hemline they used for the neckline creates such a weak stitch that the shirts areactually showing holes under the neckline after just one wash cycle (as seen inattached presentation item 2). This is unacceptable but the manufacturer is nowblaming the problems on us for “forcing them” to use blind serge stitching andfor “forcing them” to use bamboo, even when they were the ones who sourced thematerial. They refuse to take responsibility for the quality issues we areexperiencing with the sloppy stitching and the ripping necklines. We are now out$3500 and have 144 bad shirts and are 3 months behind schedule in terms of ourplanned launch date.​We do not want to go to china to make these shirts for two reasons: 1) we wantMade in USA to support the country, to keep quality in check, avoid logisticsand import costs, and for marketing/PR reasons. 2) at the beginning as we growour brand/company we will have a hard time hitting the minimums requiredoverseas.​Having said that, we feel we need to discontinue our relationship with Stock,take our patterns elsewhere with our samples and resource somewhere else in theUSA and we have been looking in LA. You mentioned you may have someone you trustthere that does good work and who may understand our vision for the alternativeto the crew and neck. I was hoping you could approach that person with oursituation and see if there is any way they would be willing to work with us toresource through them. Again, we are not stuck on Bamboo, not even that adamantabout Blind Stitching, we just want great quality, dependable and reliableproduction.​We have all the patterns, samples, production attempted shirts in all colors andsizes to use as a boilerplate. Our website is up and running and we are alreadytaking orders in our “pre-order” phase.​Your help would be appreciated as always!​Cheers!​Joel Paglione​Blunt Neck Clothing, Founder​Chicago, IL​630-360-0026​www.BluntNeck.com​

​

------ Attachment Summary of Issues Identified 02.18.2014.pdf -----

        Summary of Issues Identified

1. Loose, sloppy, and hanging stitches on bottom

 hem, and sleeve hems. Additional Info: All shirts have this issue, not specific to a certain size/color. Some are worse than others but they all look as though the shirt could come apart. In one instance already, the sleeve stitching has come loose and opened up after first wash Additional Background of the Issue: Our request was “blind serge stitching” so that the sleeves and bottom of shirt do not have obvious hems and instead the customers visual focus would be drawn towards the blunt shaped neckline. The discussion had between Tim and I was that “the structural integrity of that stitch” would not be great if we used a blind serge stitch. My interpretation was that by “Structural Integrity” we were implying that over time the hem would not be as structurally sound to withstand repeated use/washes etc. not that the shirts hems would come out of production sloppy, loose and coming apart even prior to its first wash cycle. If that was the case, obviously we wouldn’t advise to move forward with that stitch. Impacts: The impacts are two fold: 1/ customer dissatisfaction of perceived quality of the made in USA shirts; and 2/ the likelihood of the stitches coming apart and potential for returns of sold units. Courses of Action Options: 1/ rerun production with better controls on stitching. 2/ rerun production with a different stitch type if this result cannot be controlled (against our intended design spec). Or 3/ Do nothing and improve next run. Summary of Issues Identified

1.

​

  As can be seen above, loose hanging         threads not trimmed. Summary of Issues Identified

1.

​

  As can be seen above, loose stitching   coming apart, and hanging threads                 uncut. Summary of Issues Identified

1.

​

   As can be seen above, threads so loose a   index finger could go through the stitch                    loops.       Summary of Issues Identified

2. Material ripping at neckline seam.

 Additional Info: All shirts have this issue, not specific to a certain size/color but worse on white. Some are worse than others but they all exhibit holes at neckline prior to washing and worsen after first wash cycle. Additional Background of the Issue: Our request was to use dense/heavy enough bamboo (rayon) material to be durable but also extremely soft. This was not a simple request we understand because they both contradict each other. Regardless, this is going to be obviously unacceptable to the customers to have rips appearing prior and after one wash cycle. Impacts: The impact is customer dissatisfaction and high potential for returns of sold units. Courses of Action Options: 1/ rerun production with thicker heavier bamboo (rayon) material. 2/ rerun production with a different stitch type along neckline to add structural reinforcement and integrity to the neckline. Or 3/ Take back all the shirts, and reprocess them with an additional stitch under the current neckline stitch that looks exactly similar to the Yellow Shirt in next slides to add additional structural integrity (if the experts agree this would add strength to the neckline where it is currently ripping). Summary of Issues Identified

2.

​

    As can be seen above, after 1 wash very obvious holes  appearing at neckline and shirt is deformed after one wash   (deformation probably due to the fabric weight/density) Summary of Issues Identified

2.

​

  As can be seen above, hole is also appearing         at neckline of the black shirts Summary of Issues Identified

2.

​

   Proposed potential solution, reprocessing the shirts and reinforcing the  neckline with an additional stitch on neckline. We would like to show you   this shirt to better show you what we are suggesting. Again, we are not  the experts however and are not sure if a) this is possible to do after the           fact, and b) if it will help with the ripping that is occuring.

​

Are youabsolutely sure? If not, fine but we are currently holding on printing, canwe proceed with back of neck tag printing and breast logo printing with ourprinting company? Thislooks to be missing on the current production t-shirts.. could this be whatwas omitted and could be the reason why the necklines are "flimsy" and"ripping apart at the seam"?​Can we add this extra stitch which was supposed to be on the shirts anwyayssince it was on the sample I have? Can we do this post production andreprocess the shirts next week?​If so then I will bring all the shirts with me to our meeting on Tuesday tobegin the processing. BothAreill and I be out of town tomorrow through Tuesday, so please let me knowif this evening works.​Tim​Sent from my iPhone​On Feb 19, 2014, at 12:48 PM, Joel Paglione <joel.paglione@gmail.com> wrote:​I would like to request a third time a general conference call to discussnext steps. I have not heard about this so I am setting a call time and dialin below. Please dial in.​Please call into 1-888-784-0010 with conference code *5195666581* at 4pmCST.​Thanks,​Joel Paglione​630-360-0026​www.joelpaglione.com​On Feb 19, 2014, at 12:26 PM, Tim Tierney <tim@stockmfgco.com> wrote:​Joel-​Thanks for your e-mail and the organized summary of issues document. Itlooks like the issues all come down to the stitch type and a weak point atthe corners of the "blunt neck".
​As for the stitch, I suggested several times that you use a cover stitch(what we use on all Stock knits) rather than the blind stitch duringsampling and prior to production. You insisted that you needed the blindstitch aesthetic because it appears on all your "high end" t-shirts. It's aweaker stitch and has a loose appearance, but we made a sample and you saidit was perfect, so that's the stitch we used on the first production run.
​Attached is a picture of the sample you approved (on the left) and the coverstitch we use on all of own knits (on the right). You'll notice that thestitch is looser and has loose threads. I came in on my day off lastSaturday to QC your shirts because I knew you needed them asap. I made surethey looked like the sample you approved before handing them off to you. IfI had clipped every single thread, it would've taken much longer than the 5hours I spent on them and would increase the cost of the garments in thefuture as more time is needed from the operators to clip every singlehanging thread.​The cover stitch is a cleaner and stronger stitch that requires much lessattention on the QC end- there's really no reason not to use it. Iunderstand you want the invisible stitch on the exterior of the garment, butthe only way we can achieve that is by having a loose/weak stitch on theinside. I went out of my way a few months ago to do research on themachinery or attachment required to make the blind stitch for you. I wentto three separate shops in Chicago including Goldblatt's Sewing Machines inWicker Park with 50 years of experience, and they had no idea, so we askedJUKI- the premier Japanese sewing machine company and they had no ideaeither. This, to me, means that it's not a very common stitch anddefinitely not a high-end one.​It's possible that the ripping on the corners of the blunt neck is due tothe fabric, but I think the solution is a different finish or edge stitcharound the neckline, similar to the yellow shirt image you sent over (whichis a cover stitch). The yellow shirt is also a much thicker durable fabric-looks like 100% cotton. You don't see t-shirts with corners like a bluntneck- one reason could be that it creates a weak stress point. I did thebest I could sourcing what you wanted: something strong, thin, opaque, andbamboo. All of our other customers source their own fabric, but youexpressed no interest in doing so, so it was up to me to find what I thoughtwould fit the description of what you wanted. You initially wanted 100%bamboo, but that doesn't exist so I sourced the highest content of bambooavailable as all bamboo fabrics are cotton blends. There's no way I couldhave foretold that the fabric would be weak at the corners of the shirt, aswe've never made a blunt neck shirt before.
​I know you have a very impressive resume when it comes to manufacturingarmored vehicles, but unfortunately that doesn't translate into the garmentindustry. All of our other customers provide tech packs, samples, sourcetheir own fabrics and trims, etc. They've gone to school for clothingdesign, have years of experience, and a fundamental understanding of fabricproperties, stitch types, finishes, etc. They know their product inside andout prior to coming to us for production. When we take on a project fromthe ground up, there are going to be speed bumps and things will arise thatare out of our control. I know it's seemingly a simple t-shirt, but thecombination of very specific features you'd like without a general knowledgeof apparel is problematic. I did my best to guide you, but to be honestyou're not the easiest person to convince. That said, we'll do our best toremedy the situation and create a product you can stand behind. We prideourselves on our craftsmanship and do our best to meet the needs of all ourclients.
​With the shirts you have, we can try to take one apart at the hems (seamrip) and redo it with the cover stitch. If that works out, we can redo allthe shirts that way and just charge hourly for labor. As for the cornersripping, it's not the stitch, it's the fabric- so you might consider movingaway from bamboo and using cotton. Also, if you were able to get samplesyou were happy with from China and the price is right- that might be thebest play in this scenario. Made in USA is definitely a selling point, butit has to make sense on the business end.
​Let me know your thoughts,​Tim​On Tue, Feb 18, 2014 at 7:17 PM, Lucas Guariglia <lucas@rowboatcreative.com>wrote:​Perfect joel. Great rebuttal. Thanks for the time involved here.​Lucas GuarigliaRowboat Creative847.828.0944 c773.675.BOAT (2628) o​Sent from my iPhone​> On Feb 18, 2014, at 6:37 PM, Joel Paglione <joel.paglione@gmail.com>wrote:>> Tim,>> As promised, attached is a document describing the issues we are seeingwith the shirts. Please advise how we move forward. I would like to discussnext steps on a conference call with all parties involved, ie Stock andBlunt Neck. I can arrange that conference call if you advise when you andyour team would be available. We are currently holding our printing in orderto hear back on your proposed resolution but cannot wait too long, as youare aware, the delays is mistakes with material arrival have already put usweeks behind our planned launch date for our clothing line (ie ValentinesDay).>> I want to end this note by saying that we mean not to come off as being"difficult to work with". We recognize that not only you personally but yourentire team has been very kind, courteous, professional, easy to deal withand responsive thus far and we know you have gone out of your way to try andhelp make Blunt Neck successful. We want a long business relationship withStock. When my friend Ryan Beshel suggested you guys were the best, we knowhe was right and we still do feel you are one of the best manufacturersaround. We just need to dial in these processes and do whats right toimprove the issues identified in the attached. I recognize, starting aclothing line is not easy, it doesn't always work out perfectly to plan, andit can't always be perfect, or else everyone would be doing it. But I knowthat these issues are things I know you wouldn't let ship out of yourfactory if they were your clothes either without doing everything possibleto find an interim containment and permanent fix for. I appreciate your helpin advance resolving these issues.>> Let me know your thoughts asap.>> Respectfully,>> Joel Paglione> 630-360-0026​> <Summary of Issues Identified 02.18.2014.pdf>​

Body Snippet: All, Here are the results of two hard washes. See attached. Looks not bad. The extra stitch keeps the neckline flat more. But I can tell that after repeated washes it could look worse than the current
Email RTF:
All,

Here are the results of two hard washes. See attached. Looks not bad. The extra

stitch keeps the neckline flat more. But I can tell that after repeated washes

it could look worse than the current neckline.

I think the solution is thicker more dense bamboo materials. Obviously this

current fabric, especially the white, is way too thin.

Where do we go from here, well I would like to propose stock reproduces at least

our 40 white shirts we ordered using heavier white bamboo material. If this

solves the issue then we have a solution for next round.

In terms of selling this round, I believe our solution is to emphasize these

shirts are stitched using extremely natural and hence delicate fabric and

therefore the washing instructions on the neckline need to be clearly visible

and enforced. Not unlike someone who buys a knit sweater or cashmere shirt. If

the customer hard washes and uses dryer against the prescribed washing

instructions then that person is not eligible for return. Unless however the

customer insists and then following a standard "customer always right"

discipline we will replace or reimburse.

As far as future stitching, per our conversation last evening Ariell with you

and your knit expert Dave, we will experiment using a cover stitch that has

"closer" thread stitches to look less like the double stitch I am not a fan of.

Alternatively, we have two choices. One being we find a blind stitching machine

or attachment capable of creating a clean stitch or we stitch as is but keep

better attention to the machines stitching cleanliness and redo if not clean or

consider part of the scrap rate. Also trim loose threads perform a better clean

up operation post production.

Immediate next steps, if all agree via this email, I will pick up all shirts,

deliver to RowBoat Creative and ask we increase the font on the washing

instructions slightly and begin the mass printing of the 140 units we have back

of neck tags within the next 10 days per standard lead times. In terms of breast

printing, in parallel I would like to experiment using the clear printing on a

few scrap shirts we now have that I will drop off. If looks good we could

replace this operation over the 3D printing. As far as graphics tees, please

proceed with this as well per the excel sheet provided to you Lucas. Same for

the neckline "slash" on neckline same as sample made and accepted except just

slash versus whole logo and this time not discharge but instead use water

based.

Any questions please do not hesitate to call me or text me guys. Areill we

really appreciate your kind assistance and advice in resolving this matter. I

look forward to a bright future for Blunt Neck Clothing.

Thank you

Joel Paglione

630-360-0026

www.joelpaglione.com

Hear from you all then.​Joel Paglione​630-360-0026​www.joelpaglione.com​On Feb 19, 2014, at 1:01 PM, Tim Tierney <tim@stockmfgco.com> wrote:​I'm sorry, I won't be available at 4pm today; I'm working with our pattern maker until about 6. I could do a call later this evening though. Both Areill and I be out of town tomorrow through Tuesday, so please let me know if this evening works.​Tim​Sent from my iPhone​On Feb 19, 2014, at 12:48 PM, Joel Paglione <joel.paglione@gmail.com> wrote:​I would like to request a third time a general conference call to discuss next steps. I have not heard about this so I am setting a call time and dial in below. Please dial in.​Please call into 1-888-784-0010 with conference code *5195666581* at 4pm CST.​Thanks,​Joel Paglione​630-360-0026​www.joelpaglione.com​On Feb 19, 2014, at 12:26 PM, Tim Tierney <tim@stockmfgco.com> wrote:​Joel-​Thanks for your e-mail and the organized summary of issues document. It looks like the issues all come down to the stitch type and a weak point at the corners of the "blunt neck".
​As for the stitch, I suggested several times that you use a cover stitch (what we use on all Stock knits) rather than the blind stitch during sampling and prior to production. You insisted that you needed the blind stitch aesthetic because it appears on all your "high end" t-shirts. It's a weaker stitch and has a loose appearance, but we made a sample and you said it was perfect, so that's the stitch we used on the first production run.
​Attached is a picture of the sample you approved (on the left) and the cover stitch we use on all of own knits (on the right). You'll notice that the stitch is looser and has loose threads. I came in on my day off last Saturday to QC your shirts because I knew you needed them asap. I made sure they looked like the sample you approved before handing them off to you. If I had clipped every single thread, it would've taken much longer than the 5 hours I spent on them and would increase the cost of the garments in the future as more time is needed from the operators to clip every single hanging thread.​The cover stitch is a cleaner and stronger stitch that requires much less attention on the QC end- there's really no reason not to use it. I understand you want the invisible stitch on the exterior of the garment, but the only way we can achieve that is by having a loose/weak stitch on the inside. I went out of my way a few months ago to do research on the machinery or attachment required to make the blind stitch for you. I went to three separate shops in Chicago including Goldblatt's Sewing Machines in Wicker Park with 50 years of experience, and they had no idea, so we asked JUKI- the premier Japanese sewing machine company and they had no idea either. This, to me, means that it's not a very common stitch and definitely not a high-end one.​It's possible that the ripping on the corners of the blunt neck is due to the fabric, but I think the solution is a different finish or edge stitch around the neckline, similar to the yellow shirt image you sent over (which is a cover stitch). The yellow shirt is also a much thicker durable fabric- looks like 100% cotton. You don't see t-shirts with corners like a blunt neck- one reason could be that it creates a weak stress point. I did the best I could sourcing what you wanted: something strong, thin, opaque, and bamboo. All of our other customers source their own fabric, but you expressed no interest in doing so, so it was up to me to find what I thought would fit the description of what you wanted. You initially wanted 100% bamboo, but that doesn't exist so I sourced the highest content of bamboo available as all bamboo fabrics are cotton blends. There's no way I could have foretold that the fabric would be weak at the corners of the shirt, as we've never made a blunt neck shirt before.
​I know you have a very impressive resume when it comes to manufacturing armored vehicles, but unfortunately that doesn't translate into the garment industry. All of our other customers provide tech packs, samples, source their own fabrics and trims, etc. They've gone to school for clothing design, have years of experience, and a fundamental understanding of fabric properties, stitch types, finishes, etc. They know their product inside and out prior to coming to us for production. When we take on a project from the ground up, there are going to be speed bumps and things will arise that are out of our control. I know it's seemingly a simple t-shirt, but the combination of very specific features you'd like without a general knowledge of apparel is problematic. I did my best to guide you, but to be honest you're not the easiest person to convince. That said, we'll do our best to remedy the situation and create a product you can stand behind. We pride ourselves on our craftsmanship and do our best to meet the needs of all our clients.
​With the shirts you have, we can try to take one apart at the hems (seam rip) and redo it with the cover stitch. If that works out, we can redo all the shirts that way and just charge hourly for labor. As for the corners ripping, it's not the stitch, it's the fabric- so you might consider moving away from bamboo and using cotton. Also, if you were able to get samples you were happy with from China and the price is right- that might be the best play in this scenario. Made in USA is definitely a selling point, but it has to make sense on the business end.
​Let me know your thoughts,​Tim​On Tue, Feb 18, 2014 at 7:17 PM, Lucas Guariglia <lucas@rowboatcreative.com> wrote:​Perfect joel. Great rebuttal. Thanks for the time involved here.​Lucas GuarigliaRowboat Creative847.828.0944 c773.675.BOAT (2628) o​Sent from my iPhone​> On Feb 18, 2014, at 6:37 PM, Joel Paglione <joel.paglione@gmail.com> wrote:>> Tim,>> As promised, attached is a document describing the issues we are seeing with the shirts. Please advise how we move forward. I would like to discuss next steps on a conference call with all parties involved, ie Stock and Blunt Neck. I can arrange that conference call if you advise when you and your team would be available. We are currently holding our printing in order to hear back on your proposed resolution but cannot wait too long, as you are aware, the delays is mistakes with material arrival have already put us weeks behind our planned launch date for our clothing line (ie Valentines Day).>> I want to end this note by saying that we mean not to come off as being "difficult to work with". We recognize that not only you personally but your entire team has been very kind, courteous, professional, easy to deal with and responsive thus far and we know you have gone out of your way to try and help make Blunt Neck successful. We want a long business relationship with Stock. When my friend Ryan Beshel suggested you guys were the best, we know he was right and we still do feel you are one of the best manufacturers around. We just need to dial in these processes and do whats right to improve the issues identified in the attached. I recognize, starting a clothing line is not easy, it doesn't always work out perfectly to plan, and it can't always be perfect, or else everyone would be doing it. But I know that these issues are things I know you wouldn't let ship out of your factory if they were your clothes either without doing everything possible to find an interim containment and permanent fix for. I appreciate your help in advance resolving these issues.>> Let me know your thoughts asap.>> Respectfully,>> Joel Paglione> 630-360-0026​> <Summary of Issues Identified 02.18.2014.pdf>​

I was sitting there today in the morning having my coffee staring at two boxes I

taped up ready to struggle bringing down to my lobby with my coffe when I re

read your email to be clear on when you were proposing to come pick up the

boxes. And when I read that you would pick up the boxes "later tomorrow night"

as in 4/11 since this was sent 4/10 then that meant you would pick up later

tonight. Meaning you would not be coming during the day and would be coming

after I returned from work at 5pm since you said "tomorrow night" not "tomorrow

day". It would be easier for me to leave at front desk when I had time to get

the cart after work.

So - I am leaving for canada at 630pm tonight returning Sunday evening. Monday I

could drop off the boxes after 530pm. But since I wanted them complete ASAP I'm

not sure I want to give them back at all for recurring due to this

miscommunication. I sense things get complicated when we try to work together

and coordinate activities and times and dates. The risk of the logo peeling off

may not warrant the risk of delays and further issues and miscommunications that

could result by reprocessing and rearranging drop off and pick up. I think we

will live with the text printing as is this round.

Joel Paglione

630-360-0026

www.joelpaglione.com

RESENDING

​

Just another piece of information on the debate we were all having regarding the

blunt neck printing on the front of the shirts.

So my buddy bought the smoke halo shirt and loves everything about it except for

the following.

BTW, I made absolutely no comments and all I asked was, please give me any

constructive criticism you have.

"I really don't like and am happy that it's in black and very small the 'blunt

neck' next to the halo

because the shirt is already a unique design that indicates it's own brand, I

feel like it doesn't need to write 'Blunt Neck' next to the halo logo

I'm going to see if I can rub the shirt and get it to flake off

​...

if you want to make the logo on the neck more visible in some way that's good,

but I personally think that these are unique on their own and don't need to beat

you over the head with the brand​

​

​"​

Just thought you guys would be interested in hearing a customer opinion.

Joe Mastroianni

Body Snippet: We've sold 12 shirts to date and sampled about 15 shirts. I'm also interested to hear what Ryan says I will probably bump him tomorrow as it will have been a week since we last talked. Today I
Email RTF:
We've sold 12 shirts to date and sampled about 15 shirts.

I'm also interested to hear what Ryan says I will probably bump him tomorrow as

it will have been a week since we last talked. Today I took the day off on

officially to go door-to-door to six: shops in both the southside and North

Side. I've been able to go to 2 of 6 so far due to delays at Staples where I was

printing the sales sheet and made myself business cards.

One store wants 16 shirts on consignment for 30 days to try us out and if we

sell Bill buy more. Another I'm about to walk into as we speak. Will let you

know how it goes.

In order to sell shirts other than taking the day off work and going

door-to-door we need to go also and do tradeshows and trunk shows. That's how

you get your brand out there. Also we would need to invest in heavy marketing

which we are not doing it all right now. We need to do "ad words" and we need

to do the photo shoots in order to do a press release in order to do real

marketing and advertising.

One of the photo shoots is underway as we speak in The Netherlands. I couldn't

wait for Josh much longer so I had a back up plan by sending shirts to this girl

in the Netherlands was a excellent Instagram following and proof that she can

take great photos so I'm waiting for her to receive the shirts which expedited

to her and once you receive them she will take the photos and send me the photos

for $200. And we can decide if we want to use Josh for $400 as well later.

Joel Paglione

630-360-0026

www.joelpaglione.com

Name: awa-blunt-300
Subject: Re: Blunt Neck
Body Snippet: Salt- my forth product, a partnership between myself and a friend of mine who really is the brainchild of the idea. He asked me to come onboard his company about 2 months ago. This is an exciting
Email RTF:
Salt- my forth product, a partnership between myself and a friend of mine who

really is the brainchild of the idea. He asked me to come onboard his company

about 2 months ago. This is an exciting project and my first tech product. We

are totally funding it using Kickstarter. And so far we met our funding goals.

Any previous spend was completely paid for by my partner who has 80% equity.

Women's line, I have 4 samples of women's shirts I developed with a manufacturer

in china. If I used stock mfg it would have costed $10K for patterns. So I went

with china. I have a ~$30,000 quotation for women's line MOQ full production of

the four designs (crop top, tee shirt, RACERBACK crop top, and RACERBACK) in

china. This is the name of the game in overseas production volumes. The company

I found and sampled with said they would do an initial smaller order as a "

first time exception" to gain business but even that is about $5,000 and does

not cover all sizes and colors and is one time only.

Bottom line, I have spent a lot of money out of my pocket on sampling,

photoshoots, web design updates, graphics design, social media advertisements,

shipping etc that I have not asked you guys for. I have sold probably 20 shirts

total that helped recoup a portion of that expense but certainly in the hole a

few thousand on Blunt Neck already personally.

Therefore, I realized that based on what I know it would take to really kick off

inventory producing of women's line, and what it would take in advertising to

get this off the ground, it would be impossible to launch this thing right with

the money us three have right now. We need at least $45,000 to do this right.

And I remember us arguing about hundreds of dollars in the past so I know we

don't have the funding to do this.

Therefore I would like to pay you or both of you for what you put into it and

call it a day. Also, frankly I expected more interaction from you especially

Lucas, more support, more spreading the word, more contacts, more pushing. You

have not said one thing about BN on your website or IG account. Not one image

not one sentence. I am a little disappointed and I've lost my motivation to

pursue this further solely by myself with my own personal funds.

Please let me know what you want to do.

​

Joel Paglione

630-360-0026

www.joelpaglione.com

Name: awa-blunt-320
Subject: Re: Blunt Neck
Body Snippet: Lucas, maybe it's best to have a phone call to explain things to make sure we're on the same page. I'm not sure why it matters to you whether Joe decided to not be reimbursed for his
Email RTF:
Lucas, maybe it's best to have a phone call to explain things to make sure we're

on the same page. I'm not sure why it matters to you whether Joe decided to not

be reimbursed for his investment or whether you decided to let his investment

ride. Why does this have a bearing on your decision or not I do not know. I

suppose you should take that up with Joe. But three quick things that make joe's

investing different than yours: 1/ Joe did not invest any recoupable tangible

capital. For example, your investment went towards printing the shirts. Those

shirts are in inventory and can be sold to recoup the cost of your investment.

Joe's investment was used to develop the website, pay for photo shoots, and

invest in our branding. Therefore his investment is buried into non-recoupable

assets. 2/ Joe is considered a cofounder of the company and that was always the

case. If he was to decide to have me reimburse him for his investment in

exchange for his equity that the process would be a little bit more complicated

since he is a cofounder. 3/ When Joe when I first decided to start the company I

gave him 30% equity which obviously is three times yours for almost the same

monetary investment. Therefore the value of his investment is much higher than

yours and so he may decide that his investment is worth hanging onto.

Lucas to be quite honest, I'm not interested in continuing Blunt Neck the way it

is today. Please do not take this the wrong way but I expect my working members

to be active participants in building the company, branding the company,

advertising the product, paying for expenses,promoting the product, contributing

to the vision and strategy of the product. Unfortunately none of which you have

proven to me you can do. I have other companies that I am more interested in

focusing on at this stage and I know and you know the bottom line is we do not

have the necessary funding to really make this company fly. It is not easy to

start a fashion company as you know. We thought we could do it with just us with

limited investment but the truth is we needmore money lots of more money. Unless

you have rowboat loads of money that I'm not aware of that you can set aside for

additional capital investments, The company will sit idle without a big-time

investor. I have one friend that may be interested in investing in the future

but it comes as a package deal with my other companies and I'm not sure I am

comfortable giving away that much equity having you on board.

I think all in all it is fair for me to offer you your investment back and I do

not think your decision should be based on whether Joe decides to let his

investment ride or not.

As soon as you send me the signed paperwork I will speedily send you your

investment payback.

I apologize if my email comes off rude or a little too honest but I felt I

should probably be upfront with you. I hope we remain friends and continue to

network together and that this does not tarnish the relationship we have built.

The bottom line is you have yourself a wonderful company with rowboat and it

seemsbe very successful for you. And I don't want to get in the way of thatby

bog you down with blunt neck stuff.

Respectfully,

​

Joel Paglione

630-360-0026

Body Snippet: Guys, Just wanted to digest and process things before responding. I appreciate your response and understand that it can be a difficult situation to attach monetary value to time, intellectual property,
Email RTF:
Guys,

Just wanted to digest and process things before responding. I appreciate your

response and understand that it can be a difficult situation to attach monetary

value to time, intellectual property, etc. I don't really care to get into the

thick of it but there was a considerable amount of time with R&D trying to

figure out the best approach to the 3D printing, various trials, print tests

etc. All of the extraneous r&d was done myself outside of business hours because

I know we all have our separate duties and involvement for BN. I was never

intending to attach a dollar amount to this. If I am onboard with something, I

am on board.

Joel, you have mentioned a couple times your disappointment with my involvement.

To be honest, i have not pushed forward on many aspects due to my menial equity

in the company. This has not been on purpose, but simply that I must delegate my

free time accordingly. I had a feeling that there was going to be some

resistance to me not going all out for the brand and it was my initial idea to

simply ask for my shares to be somewhat reduced if I was going to be more of a

silent partner.

I obviously have the drive, elements, and resources to create and sustain a

brand/business, as do you Joel. It is just difficult to me to a lot and use all

of my resources for such a small stake in something.

nonetheless, I dont operate with any hard feelings in any aspect of my life or

business operations. The apparel industry is indeed a rough game and require a

lot of overheard to make this happen. I was quite eager to see what might happen

with the women's aspect of the brand as we all know women purchase more.

Lucas Guariglia

​Lucas,

I should have been more vocal instead of just letting you two talk about

things. I apologize for this. It was rude and unprofessional.

I have been on the same page I was since the last time I said anything. As a

co-founder, with many hours of non-documented work, planning, designs, meetings,

etc... to help create blunt neck, I am in a different position. I have not come

to an agreement with Joel over what my buyout would be. Granted, I have not

been proactive about figuring it out. With all Joel has put in, I'm nervous how

low it would be even though we started it together. I guess it would be

different if we had made thousands of dollars. I also didn't understand why my

decision would impact yours.

Just some observations; I didn't think you wanted to stay on anymore. It

seemed to me that you were very excited in the beginning, but then you lost

interest. I never saw any type of post promoting blunt neck, nor heard you

mention what you wanted to do, or progress with any of your contacts and how

they could help. I remember trunk club as an example and looking into offering

blunt neck blanks through rowboat. All in all, it just seemed like you didn't

have any interest anymore, which is fine. I have no hard feelings. Sometimes,

people simply change their minds, things come up, and I thought that was the

case.

>>>>>>>>>>>>>>> On Nov 18, 2014, at 12:01 PM, Joel.paglione@gmail.com <joel.paglione@gmail.com> wrote:

>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>

>>>>>>>>>>>>>>> Lucas, maybe it's best to have a phone call to explain things to make sure we're on the same page. I'm not sure why it matters to you whether Joe decided to not be reimbursed for his investment or whether you decided to let his investment ride. Why does this have a bearing on your decision or not I do not know. I suppose you should take that up with Joe. But three quick things that make joe's investing different than yours: 1/ Joe did not invest any recoupable tangible capital. For example, your investment went towards printing the shirts. Those shirts are in inventory and can be sold to recoup the cost of your investment. Joe's investment was used to develop the website, pay for photo shoots, and invest in our branding. Therefore his investment is buried into non-recoupable assets. 2/ Joe is considered a cofounder of the company and that was always the case. If he was to decide to have me reimburse him for his investment in exchange for his equity that the process would be a little bit more complicated since he is a cofounder. 3/ When Joe when I first decided to start the company I gave him 30% equity which obviously is three times yours for almost the same monetary investment. Therefore the value of his investment is much higher than yours and so he may decide that his investment is worth hanging onto.

>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>

>>>>>>>>>>>>>>> Lucas to be quite honest, I'm not interested in continuing Blunt Neck the way it is today. Please do not take this the wrong way but I expect my working members to be active participants in building the company, branding the company, advertising the product, paying for expenses,promoting the product, contributing to the vision and strategy of the product. Unfortunately none of which you have proven to me you can do. I have other companies that I am more interested in focusing on at this stage and I know and you know the bottom line is we do not have the necessary funding to really make this company fly. It is not easy to start a fashion company as you know. We thought we could do it with just us with limited investment but the truth is we needmore money lots of more money. Unless you have rowboat loads of money that I'm not aware of that you can set aside for additional capital investments, The company will sit idle without a big-time investor. I have one friend that may be interested in investing in the future but it comes as a package deal with my other companies and I'm not sure I am comfortable giving away that much equity having you on board.

>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>

>>>>>>>>>>>>>>> I think all in all it is fair for me to offer you your investment back and I do not think your decision should be based on whether Joe decides to let his investment ride or not.

>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>

>>>>>>>>>>>>>>> As soon as you send me the signed paperwork I will speedily send you your investment payback.

>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>

>>>>>>>>>>>>>>> I apologize if my email comes off rude or a little too honest but I felt I should probably be upfront with you. I hope we remain friends and continue to network together and that this does not tarnish the relationship we have built. The bottom line is you have yourself a wonderful company with rowboat and it seemsbe very successful for you. And I don't want to get in the way of thatby bog you down with blunt neck stuff.

>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>

>>>>>>>>>>>>>>> Respectfully,

>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>

>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>> On Nov 18, 2014, at 12:01 PM, Joel.paglione@gmail.com <joel.paglione@gmail.com> wrote:

>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>

>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>> Lucas, maybe it's best to have a phone call to explain things to make sure we're on the same page. I'm not sure why it matters to you whether Joe decided to not be reimbursed for his investment or whether you decided to let his investment ride. Why does this have a bearing on your decision or not I do not know. I suppose you should take that up with Joe. But three quick things that make joe's investing different than yours: 1/ Joe did not invest any recoupable tangible capital. For example, your investment went towards printing the shirts. Those shirts are in inventory and can be sold to recoup the cost of your investment. Joe's investment was used to develop the website, pay for photo shoots, and invest in our branding. Therefore his investment is buried into non-recoupable assets. 2/ Joe is considered a cofounder of the company and that was always the case. If he was to decide to have me reimburse him for his investment in exchange for his equity that the process would be a little bit more complicated since he is a cofounder. 3/ When Joe when I first decided to start the company I gave him 30% equity which obviously is three times yours for almost the same monetary investment. Therefore the value of his investment is much higher than yours and so he may decide that his investment is worth hanging onto.

>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>

>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>> Lucas to be quite honest, I'm not interested in continuing Blunt Neck the way it is today. Please do not take this the wrong way but I expect my working members to be active participants in building the company, branding the company, advertising the product, paying for expenses,promoting the product, contributing to the vision and strategy of the product. Unfortunately none of which you have proven to me you can do. I have other companies that I am more interested in focusing on at this stage and I know and you know the bottom line is we do not have the necessary funding to really make this company fly. It is not easy to start a fashion company as you know. We thought we could do it with just us with limited investment but the truth is we needmore money lots of more money. Unless you have rowboat loads of money that I'm not aware of that you can set aside for additional capital investments, The company will sit idle without a big-time investor. I have one friend that may be interested in investing in the future but it comes as a package deal with my other companies and I'm not sure I am comfortable giving away that much equity having you on board.

>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>

>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>> I think all in all it is fair for me to offer you your investment back and I do not think your decision should be based on whether Joe decides to let his investment ride or not.

>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>

>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>> As soon as you send me the signed paperwork I will speedily send you your investment payback.

>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>

>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>> I apologize if my email comes off rude or a little too honest but I felt I should probably be upfront with you. I hope we remain friends and continue to network together and that this does not tarnish the relationship we have built. The bottom line is you have yourself a wonderful company with rowboat and it seemsbe very successful for you. And I don't want to get in the way of thatby bog you down with blunt neck stuff.

>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>

>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>> Respectfully,

>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>

>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>> Joel Paglione

>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>> On Nov 18, 2014, at 12:01 PM, Joel.paglione@gmail.com <joel.paglione@gmail.com> wrote:

>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>

>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>> Lucas, maybe it's best to have a phone call to explain things to make sure we're on the same page. I'm not sure why it matters to you whether Joe decided to not be reimbursed for his investment or whether you decided to let his investment ride. Why does this have a bearing on your decision or not I do not know. I suppose you should take that up with Joe. But three quick things that make joe's investing different than yours: 1/ Joe did not invest any recoupable tangible capital. For example, your investment went towards printing the shirts. Those shirts are in inventory and can be sold to recoup the cost of your investment. Joe's investment was used to develop the website, pay for photo shoots, and invest in our branding. Therefore his investment is buried into non-recoupable assets. 2/ Joe is considered a cofounder of the company and that was always the case. If he was to decide to have me reimburse him for his investment in exchange for his equity that the process would be a little bit more complicated since he is a cofounder. 3/ When Joe when I first decided to start the company I gave him 30% equity which obviously is three times yours for almost the same monetary investment. Therefore the value of his investment is much higher than yours and so he may decide that his investment is worth hanging onto.

>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>

>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>> Lucas to be quite honest, I'm not interested in continuing Blunt Neck the way it is today. Please do not take this the wrong way but I expect my working members to be active participants in building the company, branding the company, advertising the product, paying for expenses,promoting the product, contributing to the vision and strategy of the product. Unfortunately none of which you have proven to me you can do. I have other companies that I am more interested in focusing on at this stage and I know and you know the bottom line is we do not have the necessary funding to really make this company fly. It is not easy to start a fashion company as you know. We thought we could do it with just us with limited investment but the truth is we needmore money lots of more money. Unless you have rowboat loads of money that I'm not aware of that you can set aside for additional capital investments, The company will sit idle without a big-time investor. I have one friend that may be interested in investing in the future but it comes as a package deal with my other companies and I'm not sure I am comfortable giving away that much equity having you on board.

>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>

>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>> I think all in all it is fair for me to offer you your investment back and I do not think your decision should be based on whether Joe decides to let his investment ride or not.

>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>

>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>> As soon as you send me the signed paperwork I will speedily send you your investment payback.

>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>

>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>> I apologize if my email comes off rude or a little too honest but I felt I should probably be upfront with you. I hope we remain friends and continue to network together and that this does not tarnish the relationship we have built. The bottom line is you have yourself a wonderful company with rowboat and it seemsbe very successful for you. And I don't want to get in the way of thatby bog you down with blunt neck stuff.

>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>

>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>> Respectfully,

>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>

>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>> Joel Paglione

>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>> 630-360-0026

Hi all,

I am out of office until Monday but needed to take time away from my Honeymoon

to inform that the entire order of the Pony Pilsner bandanas were rejected by

the client. This were received late and the quality was beyond acceptable.

These were not printed with waterbase ink as previously discussed and were also

received for the client with terrible registration, ink pickup, and thick

deposits of ink. We have attached multiple supporting photos which we random

pieces we pulled from them entire order.

We will need to not only have this invoice voided but also receive reimbursement

for the blanks we provided. We not only experienced client loss impact on this,

needed to refund their order and are now out of pocket for this. Obviously we

are not happy about how all orders have gone with Texpressions.

Please confirm receipt as we are hoping to close all these chapters and

unfortunate service we have received not only by me personally but additional

Your Complaint

Haul Bikes / Daily direct services were hired to transport my newly refurbished

admitting fault in writing several times. After continued delay, I was forced to

hire an attorney in hopes of resolution. Again the owner admitted fault but

refused to make good on repairs. At NO point was I offered the option to pay the

insurance deductible which was additional coverage I paid for. My attorney and I

have been told by former employees of Haul Bikes that the insurance coverage is

a scam where no damage is ever repaired and the company pockets the additional

coverage. I demand a full refund ($450) + $250 for insurance deductible as I was

forced to file a personal claim which will be subrogated. I am happy to provide

all correspondence which includes the owner Jeff Lloyd's refusal to provide

legal contact or communication with my attorney after openly admitting fault.

There has also been a formal complaint filed with the Bureau of Better Business

which has also seen the company's refusal of action after agreeing to refund

payment, as well as repairing damages they caused. Previous employees have

warned of their operations and how they treat consumers even after admitting

guilt.

Name: LG-VS-AB-100
Subject: Astor & Black - negative experience
Body Snippet: Hi Joe, I received your email from my wife back in December. Did not have any immediate need to reach out as I thought a current situation was under control. I purchased 3 customs via Greg for my
Email RTF:
Hi Joe,

I received your email from my wife back in December. Did not have any immediate need to reach out as I thought a current situation was under control.

​

I purchased 3 customs via Greg for my wedding and rehearsal dinner. There were several hiccups along the way which I tried to overlook since this was my first time utilizing custom.

​

The day of my rehearsal, I took a close look at the custom skull jacket and realized the lining was beginning to separate. With no time to remedy I had to go with it. After decompressing from the wedding I notified Greg of the issue and supplied the attached video. This was dated October 9. I was assured this

would be taken care of as I had several upcoming events I would have preferred to wear the jacket for. Again, repeated lack of follow up and it is now Jan 20 and I have no jacket or actual update.

​

I have been told several times that communication is now tough since he left the company, however this has absolutely nothing to do with me.

​

Beyond feeling like I should be compensated for the countless days of runaround, I still have NO jacket. This was extremely personal to me as it was from my wedding and being told that it was being scraped and probably re-made didn’t sit well but I thought it was what it was.

​

I am hoping someone can get to the bottom of this and relay actual answers and timeline.

​

Really a bummer that this was my first experience as the wind has certainly been taken out of my sails to have to deal with this ever again.

​

Please advise and thanks for your time.
TO (name): Joe Chay, Bryan Grieser, Kaitlyn Huffman
To (all info): Joe Chay <joe@astorandblack.com>, Bryan Grieser <bryan@astorandblack.com>, Kaitlyn Huffman <kaitlyn@astorandblack.com>

Name: LG-VS-AB-101
Subject: Re: Astor & Black - negative experience
Body Snippet: Hi Lucas, My name is Bryan and I handle the production for A&B. Greg made me aware of your situation just before he left the company and we have been working on getting your jacket back to you
Email RTF:
Hi Lucas,

My name is Bryan and I handle the production for A&B. Greg made me aware of your situation just before he left the company and we have been working on getting your jacket back to you since. Your jacket is currently in production and will be finished as soon as our factory opens back up from their New Year holiday break. I certainly understand your concerns with regards to the lack of follow-up. We were allowing Greg to handle the outstanding orders he had remaining in production, however this will now be handled by myself & Joe. We will get your jacket done as soon as possible which should be at the beginning of Feb. or shortly thereafter.

​

We do apologize for the delay. We look forward to getting your jacket finished and delivered to you with hopes to regain your trust.

​

Should you have any more questions please feel free to get a hold of myself or Joe and we would be happy to help you.

Name: LG-VS-AB-108
Subject: Re: Astor & Black - negative experience
Body Snippet: Joe, Hope yo have been well during these crazy times. I have just returned back to Chicago since being out of state for business and then quarantine due to COVID-19. I just received and opened the
Email RTF:
Joe,

Hope yo have been well during these crazy times. I have just returned back to Chicago since being out of state for business and then quarantine due to COVID-19. I just received and opened the shipment of the replacement skull jacket.

I am very sorry to say that the opposite of what we discussed happened in mfg. The new jacket is now smaller than the original which was included. I can feel even more pulling on the back which you and I discussed that more room would

actually be given to mitigate the ripping at the seam from the delicate lining.

​

I tried the original on and it fits WAY better as a custom jacket should. At this point, it kills me to have to open this can of worms again but I would simply like my money back. This has been an exhausting experience starting even with Greg involved. I personally paid a lot of money for multiple items from your company that I am just not happy with. I have multiple colleagues in the custom suiting business and ultimately went with Greg because of personal

referral. I was most looking forward to this skull piece and really just bummed at what this has become as a memory of my wedding and ultimately something that doesn't fit as a $1600 jacket would fit. As I business owner myself, I

understand the impact of negative reviews and BBB reports. I am not looking to go this route if we can just close this route as I know none of this has been intentional on either side. Simply circumstance.

Please let me know the best way to process this refund. My bank has record of the incident from previous discussions when I was unable to receive response in the beginning. I had them hold as you and I were trying to work this out. I really thought we would be able to resolve this.

​

Thank you in advance.
notes: LG gains weight and blames tailor. Then calls BBB and then contests the charges. PS. LG wears the jacket all the time. Most recently LG wore the jacket covered in skulls in horrible taste to the funeral of our best friend Javier Chaparro.

Name: LG-VS-BAUM-100
Subject: 4200 W Diversey Fire
Body Snippet: Dear Tali and Baum Team, As you are all aware, there was a fire at the property yesterday which stemmed from the negligence of Baum's roofing contractor and continued to progress based on
Email RTF:
Dear Tali and Baum Team,

As you are all aware, there was a fire at the property yesterday which stemmed from the negligence of Baum's roofing contractor and continued to progress based on Baum's negligence to maintain the building. One would think that a fire on the premises itself would be the most concerning part of what occurred, however, in this case the most concerning part was that there were no fire alarms and no sprinklers. My clients only became aware of the fire when they smelled it and it and ash began closing into their space. Then, Lucas from Rowboat was actually the person who called 911, NOT the roofers whom caused the fire and were already made aware of it. Had my clients not called 911 it is likely much more damage would have occurred including a potential building explosion given the adjacent tenant Letherbee Distillery.

That being said, you can imagine Rowboat and its clients are infuriated. Not only has my clients space been damaged, shipments were missed yesterday as employees were unable to work in the environment, they cannot operate at their

facility, their clients products have been damaged, and their clients are actually firing them. Moreover, my clients lives and the lives of their employees were put at risk along with the rest of the building. My clients have both video and pictures of burning debris falling into their unit while no fire alarms or sprinklers were going off, burning embers falling from the

ceiling and burner Joe’s face as a result of roofers trying to merely stomp the fire out, and more that we will withhold for our case. It should be noted that the fire was not more than mere feet from a sprinkler head. Baum is clearly in violation of the building code for failing to provide a working fire alarm,

failing to provide working sprinklers, and failing to properly install fire doors with operable exit signs, as the firefighters could not find the signs through the smoke. Though a reasonable person would assume such an egregious situation could be easily handled without litigation, given Baum's constant refusal to take responsibility for its actions and our history it seems litigation is inevitable. Rowboat’s litigation attorney’s have been contacted as we continue to prepare to pursue action to the utmost degree against not only Matthew’s Roofing but also Baum Revisions.

​

At this time, we demand that documentation regarding all previous City Inspections, Fire Inspections and fire alarms be provided immediately. Further, we expect our space to be restored immediately, with no cost to us, and damages for all the product, machinery, and furniture paid immediately upon request. It is now 3:30pm with no insurance adjusters arriving on-site as Rowboat was told multiple times they would today. My clients have been forced to show clients the extent of the damage and are now fielding call after call as to reparations.

Lastly, it seems we will be losing some very large clients based on Baum's reluctance to properly maintain a building as landlords. You will be advised of those relationships and the lost income shortly, as Baum's negligence is the sole reason these relationships are being terminated.
