Subject: follow up and comments on the bell printing process
Body Snippet: Hi Lucas, Im following up on your order and wanted to know if you received our invoice. There is one thing we wanted to let you know, the logo on the sleeve is impossible to achieve with this type of
Email RTF:
Hi Lucas,

​

Im following up on your order and wanted to know if you received our invoice.

​

There is one thing we wanted to let you know, the logo on the sleeve is

impossible to achieve with this type of process (all over)

​

Since we will be doing all over, the art from the all over print will hit

different places on the garment that wont leave too much space most of the time,

for a proper printing on the sleeve.

​

If you are in town we can show you in our shop how the process work for this

type of production.

​

If you have any questions please give us a call.

​

Best regards

​

Lixandro Cordero

​

   T Expressions Designs

​

     (702) 643-0028 |  (702) 643-0075

​

   sales@texpressionsdesigns.com

Good afternoon,

​

I just wanted to offer our services and partner with Rowboat Creative to extend

your capabilities of creation. We partner with several big printer companies

where we do the backgrounds (allover print or different techniques) and they do

the smaller hits. We are just wondering if you guys would be interested in this.

If you have any questions, comments or concern please let us know. Hoping that

we can create big things and looking forward for this year.

​

Regards,

​

Jesus Lopez

​

T Expressions Designs

Email RTF:
All,

Please see the attached and notes.

Josh: As you and I discussed, this client is extremely unhappy with the fact

that they did not receive product for the firm in-hands date previously noted on

the PO we submitted. Moreover, they even more displeased that the product they

received did not match to their approved sample we sited.

Direct notes from client:

• Sleeve print was supposed to be on the LEFT sleeve, not RIGHT. Josh and I

discussed this but we will need to have client go through entire order to report

total amount of tees with imprint on incorrect sleeve.

• PMS color is OFF. Approved sample was 347c and the full production run is very

dark. (See attached supporting photos)

• Enterprise logo on sleeve registration is off (e box is separated). They

rejected due to quality as these do to meet their corporate branding identity

standards.

Overall, the only solve is to have the order fully replaced. Prior to speaking

with the client we need full transparent and realistic turn time to have you

replace this order.

Please let me know by tomorrow 10a CST as we have a scheduled call with

Enterprise’s legal department and executives to address this matter.

Thanks.

​

All,

Creating a separate thread so all parties have full clarity.

In addition to the other 2 orders delivered beyond firm in-hands dates noted,

Josh and I spoke about the 2 remaining bandana orders Jay from our team

processed weeks ago with Texpressions. As with the other orders, the client is

extremely unhappy and we will experience both monetary and client loss as a

result.

Josh assured me yesterday that the remaining banana orders would be completing

this morning and will ship for overnight AM delivery to our Chicago location

today. It is absolutely imperative that we receive these tomorrow AM.

Please confirm and provide tracking asap today. We are hesitant to relay any

information to our client without seeing tracking in motion as we have been told

orders were being shipped out when they were actually not in the past, resulting

in clients showing up to pickup with no product arriving.

We are all very upset and disappointed in how things have transpired with what

could have been a fruitful business relationship.

Let’s close these chapters.

Email RTF:
All,

We have now completely lost this client as a result of repeated negligence on

this project. As discussed, the order was rejected for numerous QC issues beyond

missing their event date. Please see remarks direct from Enterprise whom is also

escalating to seek monetary damages.

"I discussed with the Account Manager and we really don't feel comfortable

moving forward with a replacement order.

We have tied up a TON of time on this project and we can't show or sell this

product on behalf of the client after showing them the spec sample. We

addressed the PMS color variance on the first round of spec samples. and

mentioned how PARTICULAR the client was about having the PMS color exact. We

have been frustrated on this project and we advocated on your behalf.

At this point, I'm not going to address going thru the order to QC whether or

not the sleeve imprint was incorrect on all bc the incorrect PMS color is enough

for us to not accept this order. We can't risk waiting another 2-4 weeks and

this being incorrect again.”

At this point we need to not only refund the order in full but also re-imburse

for the full order of blanks.

Please have your accounting note that this invoice will not be paid and we will

need to figure out replacement cost for all blanks.

Please respond within the hour as it is in all of our best interest to avoid

legal action from a client of this size.

​

_______________________________

Email RTF:
Hi all,

I am out of office until Monday but needed to take time away from my Honeymoon

to inform that the entire order of the Pony Pilsner bandanas were rejected by

the client. This were received late and the quality was beyond acceptable.

These were not printed with waterbase ink as previously discussed and were also

received for the client with terrible registration, ink pickup, and thick

deposits of ink. We have attached multiple supporting photos which we random

pieces we pulled from them entire order.

We will need to not only have this invoice voided but also receive reimbursement

for the blanks we provided. We not only experienced client loss impact on this,

needed to refund their order and are now out of pocket for this. Obviously we

are not happy about how all orders have gone with Texpressions.

Please confirm receipt as we are hoping to close all these chapters and

unfortunate service we have received not only by me personally but additional

caused us? All orders that were received from your facility were beyond

compensation as they have repeatedly been threatening legal damages against us.

relayed, missed dates, incorrect production, and a beyond horrible experience

Email RTF:
Hi Stephanie!

Hope you had a great weekend.

Just wanted to keep communication moving forward and as transparent as possible

to hopefully align when the timing is right for both sides.

We have been dissecting the breakouts for Success vs Evolve and wondering if

there is a bit of hybrid model that might work. The $3200/mo is a pretty large

increase from our previous firm / firms over the years. I would be hesitant to

only opted for the Evolve package based on pricing alone as we are looking to

scale up this potential relationship to be hopefully a permanent one. I also

think it might be confusing to cherry pick some elements from the Success

package or to attribute a cost to any of the line items to remove them to meet

our intended budget.

Let me know your thoughts so we can continue proactively working towards a

fruitful relationship and potential launch for both sides.

Thanks!

Name: Spark-em-177
Subject: RE: Chase Assignment
Body Snippet: Hi Guys! Thank you for being straightforward and letting me know your concerns, and allowing me to clarify. I do not want to start on the wrong foot here. I am genuinely concerned or confused about the
Email RTF:
Hi Guys!​Thank you for being straightforward and letting me know your concerns, andallowing me to clarify. I do not want to start on the wrong foot here. I amgenuinely concerned or confused about the discrepancy in what we had discussedregarding what the onboarding process would look like versus what you areexperiencing now. We had discussed a target wrap date of the end of the monthand we are on track with that and working hard to get everything up to speed. Ifyou are watching us work in QBO, you will see things in holding patterns whilewe learn your vendors and the nuances of operations; this is 100% normal andstandard. The ASK account is a holding account that we utilize as a morepersonalized uncategorized account. We will continue to remove items from hereas we investigate and learn until we are officially wrapped, and ultimately wewill bring all of these to you at once for efficiency’s sake. For thishistorical work, it would be by the end of this month; for your package andmonthly work, it will be monthly and bi-weekly. We do this so we are notconstantly disturbing the business owners with questions and our clients arevery happy with this approach. For time spent, I always state that ourhistorical and clean-up work is a best estimate based on our working knowledgebut is variable based on what is uncovered during the process. In your case, weare really on track time-wise, so I did not shoot you an update with that info;we have all that detail in our invoice.​Regarding billing, I was under the impression that my colleague who handlesbilling had reached out directly. I apologize if there remains any confusion, Itend to defer to her on this. You were billed a retainer and charged for that.During hourly work, we will invoice twice a month with detailed descriptions ofour work; those invoices per your contract are due within three to five businessdays of receipt and are charged to the account on file; that is a firm policy.In monthly packages, it is the same; only it is once a month. During the threeto five business days, you are welcome to update or change that account on file.​For immediate conversations, admittedly, this is a bit of a hectic time withstaff out due to illness, vacations, etc., and also, for these specificquestions, I am your main point of contact. In the future, with more generalaccount and bookkeeping-related questions, you do have a team, and because ofthat, response time is typically immediate from one of us.​Thanks again for letting me know and I hope this helps to clear things up. Ifanything remains unclear or is a concern, please let me know. Have a great timetoday at your event!​From: Lucas Guariglia <lucas@rowboatcreative.com>Sent: Friday, July 22, 2022 8:59 AMTo: Stephanie Morin <stephanie@sparkbusinessconsulting.com>Cc: Joe Zangrilli <joe@rowboatcreative.com>Subject: Re: Chase Assignment​Hi Stephanie,​We have questions as to how things are being reconciled and booked etc. Joe isable to see some elements in QBO but mentioned there are a lot that just say“ask Lucas” but no one has reached out.​Secondly we are confused about billing. Email RTF:
Hi Lucas!

​

I apologize for my delay in reply. Stephanie was on vacation, but she responded,

and I wasn’t sure if I should jump in or not. However, I did end up spending a

significant amount of time between yesterday and today working on your account,

and cleaning up the file for 2021. Here are my results:

​

Open Items / Balance Sheet (also reflected on the shared spreadsheet):

​

1. 9710 PPP bank account – is this bank account still open with $4,076.97

available?

2. Accounts Receivable – I reviewed the spreadsheet that Stephanie had shared

with you and determined that the Open Invoices tab has not been reviewed

3. Undeposited funds have 3 payments totaling $9,218.21 received from customers

that I was unable to match to deposits:  a. 8/13/21 for $130.37 from Estereo  b. 9/28/21 for $37.84 from 8MATIKRECORDZ P  c. 11/30/21 for $9,050 from GTI

4. Accounts Payable – I reviewed the spreadsheet that Stephanie had shared with

you and determined that the Unpaid Bills tab has not been reviewed

5. Due to Classick Studios is showing you owe $842.65 after making a payment on

2/3/21 – does this seem accurate?

6. Due to Creative Who Care is showing they owe you $1,338.96 with last

activity being 9/22/21 – does this seem accurate?

7. Illinois Department of Revenue Payable is showing that there is a sales tax

liability of $70,061.23 as of 12/31/21 – we were given a link to access aGoogle Drive but when I click on it I get an error message that we don’thave access. I just sent a request for access.

8. PPP Loan – did you receive any PPP forgiveness?

  a. round 1 for $195,805 on 4/20/2020  b. round 2 for $108,145 on 3/12/2021  c. funds transfer from Fifth Third Checking on 10/4/21 for $30,879.58 -     was this a payment towards the PPP Loans?

9. Attached are the open items from the P&L

​

Closed items / Balance Sheet:

​

1. Bank account has been cleaned up with the follow checks not cleared as of

12/31/21:  a. 4/7/21 for $1,333.57 to Alberto Garcia  b. 11/11/21 for $2,445.02 to Phillips Air Compressor, Inc.  c. 12/24/21 for $2,445.02 to Illinois DOR for Sales Tax

2. Due from JZ and Due from LG are probably adjusted when taxes are filed

3. The credit card subaccounts are a nonissue. They all come together to the

Chase Credit Cards header account, which appears to be reconciled andreflect an accurate balance.

4. Direct Deposit Payable is accurate

5. Payroll Liabilities are accurate

6. Retail Sales Tax Payable old had an outstanding balance of $4,105.25 as of

12/31/2020, we moved this to the current sales tax account, per yourinstruction on the spreadsheet Stephanie shared with you

​

Specific to 2022 transactions:

​

1. I’ve attached a PDF showing 2 payments that were not made to the entities

for payroll taxes. I believe it was due to a transition between the PPP bankaccount and the regular opex. Did you make these payments? I saw a paymentfor $1,455 made to the IL DOR on 3/23/22, which had ??? on the spreadsheetthat Stephanie had shared with you. I wonder if it might be the IL IncomeTax payment of $1,097.93 plus penalties, fees, etc.?

2. I did review the uncategorized tab in the spreadsheet Stephanie sent you and

made a column called “Spark Notes” with progress made. A lot of the Posweren’t in QBO, but it might be because they are in the Sanmar or S&S tabs,which didn’t have enough information for me to add the Pos to QBO.

3. Direct Capital Loans for the Image Machine appears to have been paid off on

5/16/22, with the payment being $379 higher than the rest. I put the $379towards interest to zero out the loan.

​

Sorry, this email is so long. I hope it helps!

​

Thank you,

​

Jackie

​

I hope you are both doing well! I am sure you are relieved to have 2021 behind

you officially. I believe that we have completed everything requested from

Sherri.

​

I have copied Jackie on this email as she is the best person to answer a billing

question. She can confirm, but she is out of the office at the moment, so she

may not be able to get right back to you. I believe it has to do with how you

requested splitting your payments, but I am not 100% sure of that.

​

Instead of pro-rating for not being able to jump into Profit First and other

items, we included the additional clean-up hours that sprung up into your

Hi Lucas & Joe,​We sent you invoices on 7/15, 7/31, 8/31 (for all of August), and 9/15. Therefore, the 8/31 invoice was forservices for the entire month of August.​When I made the 8/31 and 9/15 invoices, I reviewed your new contract, the timespent, and the previous invoices we sent. You had invoices on 7/15 and 7/31 thattotaled $2,541.25. Rather than send you invoices on 8/31 and 9/15 billed hourly,which would have resulted in invoices over your newly selected package andbehind two invoices in July that were substantial, I opted to send you 8/31 and9/15 invoices for your package rate. I did this because (1) I thought it wouldbe clearer to get your package rate selection rather than send you invoices forhigher than your package, (2) it was more advantageous for you, and (3) this wasall done in the spirit of fostering our new relationship. Plus, I think we allwanted to put 2021 behind us!​The invoice you received for $2,200 dated 8/31 was sent toaccounting@rowboatcreative.com on 9/1 @ 7:06 pm. The 9/15 invoice was the firstsplit package invoice, which is for time spent between 9/1-9/15. We sent it on9/16 at 8:53 pm to the same email address. I'm confused about how you receivedthe 8/31 invoice but not the 9/15 one. Our records indicate that the email wassent successfully and was viewed by you, but maybe that's a shared email or aglitch on our end. Name: Spark-em-299
Subject: RE: Invoice 40596 from Spark Business Consulting
Body Snippet: Hi Lucas & Joe, As promised, I would like to email back and respond to your concerns. At the onset of your first contract, we were tasked with getting 2022 current. At the beginning of your second
Email RTF:
Hi Lucas & Joe,​As promised, I would like to email back and respond to your concerns.​At the onset of your first contract, we were tasked with getting 2022 current.At the beginning of your second contract, we were charged with weeklymaintenance of your account and full AR & AP as agreed upon before thecontract’s execution. One week after the second contract was executed, Monday,August 22^nd, you contacted us to ask if we would have 2021 ready for Sheri bythe end of the week. We were never told that we would have anything to do with2021. An account of your size, with no notice and a one-week time frame tocomplete a clean-up of an entire year that we did not work on, was a significantrequest. If any other company had come to us with this request, we would haveplanned and advised that we would need two months to turn it around. Since wehad little lead time and a deadline, Stephanie brought me into the fold. Weworked as quickly as possible and cleaned the bare minimum that would be neededfor the taxes to be completed timely, and this came at the expense of theimplementation of the new package you were expecting to be transitioned into.​While we were working on completing 2021, Stephanie was on a call where she wasspoken to in a manner that was not acceptable. As uncomfortable as it was, shemaintained professionalism during the call and after when she emailed to clearthe air and move forward. We told ourselves that you were in a very stressfulsituation and not to take it personally as everyone has bad days. After 2021 wascompleted, we were met with emails questioning our billing and the services wewere providing, accusing us of charging you for something we shouldn’t. I wastaken aback by the inquiry, given the time and energy we spent on getting 2021done for you, while I also tried to make sure everything else was squared awayfor my vacation. I told myself that you did not necessarily understand that yourrequest for us to process 2021 came at the expense of implementing your currentservice/package and that your inquiry about the billing came across asaccusatory. I did my best to explain simply that given the timing of your newcontract and in the spirit of fostering our new relationship, I opted to chargeyou for your package rate rather than hourly as it was more advantageous to you.I had hoped to put the inappropriate behavior and accusatory tones behind us andmove forward.​After 2021 was closed, we had to go back and take care of 2022, which was put onthe back burner due to the rush project. We were met with another emailquestioning our billing and telling us to hold off before processing payment asyou didn’t feel you were getting the current services you were expecting. Fromour perspective, this was the second email we received from you that appeared toundervalue the work we had completed and questioned our integrity/delivery ofservices being billed, which you know had been discounted on more than oneoccasion. We spent time outside of business hours to complete tasks we weren’texpecting to do, work as hard as we could to get current to finally get to thegood stuff (profit first and diving into recent numbers to start actualconsulting), and in return received multiple emails disputing our bills andaccusing us of charging for services not rendered – THAT is where the “FOR FUCKSSAKE” came from. You are not bothering us by asking questions! There is nothingwe want MORE than for our clients to ask questions so that they fully understandthe invoicing process. We want our clients to be overjoyed with our service andunderstand and appreciate what they are paying for. It might sound crazy, butour goal is for all of our clients to see our transactions on their bankstatements and smile when they think about what they received for it!​Now we are in receipt of a third email from you disputing that we had to finishthe cleanup we couldn’t complete before the tax deadline. From the beginning ofour correspondence, we have made it clear that clean-up and historical arebilled hourly. This occurred in an email dated 5/16/22, your first contractdated 6/24/22, and your second contract dated 8/17/22. You have also receivedinvoices that were hourly, so I am surprised to hear that you are disputing thehourly charges for the historical clean-up work that you approved when you saidthat the AP and AR from 2021 and prior could be cleaned up by us, which neededto be done to make your books current and accurate for us to provide theservices you are looking for.​For the third time, we are receiving an email accusing us of not delivering theservices you are paying for. We are updating as agreed upon, building out yourchart of accounts, and providing value in scrubbing your books. To accuratelyrecord and categorize all ACH transactions, we needed access to a secondarybanking profile with full admin rights. To reconcile AR accurately, we need toknow what statuses and tags you use to run reports in Printavo. To clean up ARand AP, we require your feedback and approval on what should be removed. Whenyou signed your first contract, we sent you a welcome email with two videosexplaining in detail that we need access for us to provide the services you arerequesting. We only ask for what we need to do to do our job and are only asgood as the information we receive. If you are not forthcoming or there aredelays in getting this information, which is all requested upon signing thecontract, it delays our ability to review and analyze the financials deeply.There is zero to gain in doing a detailed review of inaccurate or half-completenumbers. There is nothing we would love more than to have completed your profitassessment and implemented profit first, but we can only produce a profitassessment with books that are current and accurate.​If you would like to continue working together, there needs to be a level oftrust established for us to be given the information we need to do our jobs andbe paid timely for the services we are performing as well as mutual respect forall parties involved as business professionals. There should be a discussionabout expectations from all parties so that we are on the same page movingforward. We are here to help you, we want to start profit first, and we want tostart consulting on current and accurate books, but this is a two-way street. Ifboth parties cannot do what is necessary and cannot treat each otherrespectfully, there may be a company that will better meet your needs. Just soyou know – the invoice you received is legitimate and due by Monday, November7^th.​I will email again later this week once Kasey, Stephanie, and I can connect tosend you some times that work for us next week.​Thank you,​Jackie​From: Joseph Zangrilli <joe@rowboatcreative.com>Sent: Wednesday, November 2, 2022 11:27 AMTo: Jaclyn Torrey <Jackie@sparkbusinessconsulting.com>Cc: Lucas Guariglia <lucas@rowboatcreative.com>; Stephanie Morin<stephanie@sparkbusinessconsulting.com>Subject: Re: Invoice 40596 from Spark Business Consulting​Jackie,​Next week would be good, if that works for Kasey. We’ll keep an eye out for theresponse.​Have a great day!​

Joe Zangrilli

Body Snippet: Hi everyone, Thank you to all who participated in the call this morning, and we are so excited that you are so close to the meat and potatoes of your services with us here at Spark. This is a quick
Email RTF:
Hi everyone,

​

Thank you to all who participated in the call this morning, and we are so

excited that you are so close to the meat and potatoes of your services with us

here at Spark. This is a quick email as a follow-up to our call this morning.

​

To summarize:

​

1. Historical clean-up is now 98% complete, and with your feedback, it should

be 100% complete by Friday! There will be no more billed time outside ofyour package for clean-up.

2. A running google sheet of action items from Steph with a separate tab from

Joe/Lucas will be created for weekly updates.

3. A monthly financial call is to be scheduled, preferably on a different day

than Friday, with enough lead time to review the previous week’s updatebefore the call.

4. Once we receive the AR tags to use in Printavo and AR in QBO that should be

closed out, we will be ready for the next step!

5. I may be off here, but it sounds like the payroll needs to be broken out to

know who is a cost of goods vs. who is overhead/expense. If I am right, itshould be updated before a PF assessment (not required, but a good idea ifit can happen). I can assist with the QuickBooks payroll side.

​

New information:

​

6. I created a shared Google Drive FOLDER so that you can find all shared docs

inside one folder. I find that helpful because otherwise, you’re searchingin your shared files for many different documents.

7. Joe had mentioned during the call that he could go into the Ask Joe & Lucas

category to make updates and put things where they go in QuickBooks. We ranout of time during the call, but from here on out, it would be best if Joe &Lucas do not make changes in QuickBooks. Please review that category andupdate the google sheet so Spark/Stephanie can make the appropriate changesin QuickBooks when applicable.  a. bank accounts to be reconciled, and occasionally the first Tuesday will not

allow enough time. It sets us up for constant rescheduling. If we could do the

second Tuesday, that would be great.

enough lead time but moving forward, I prefer to confirm and commit to a time

that allows for that reconciliation and review window.

separate email already.

Rowboat Creative

​

    Re: Profit First Assessment    1/9/2023

​

Hi Joseph & Lucas,

​

I am thrilled to present to you your full Profit ECROP, AKA, the Evaluation, Conversion & Roll Out Plan for

your business. To create this assessment, I have used the following:

​

●   The 2021- and 2022-Income Statement, Balance Sheet, and Cash Flow reports from your QBO file.●   Our firm’s experience with other clientele who are achieving the profit objectives that you are    targeting.

​

This report documents both your current financial trend, and a plan to achieve your profit objectives.

​

As our next step, I will begin making allocations as discussed in our Kickoff Meeting. As you adjust to this

cash management system, please do not hesitate to reach out, I am more than happy to answer any

questions or concerns you have about the implementation and roll out process. I am looking forward to a

very profitable 2023!

​

Sincerely,

​

Stephanie Morin

Master Profit First Professional

                                      PROFIT ASSESSMENT                                              for                                       Rowboat Creative

​

Overview

This report is a concise, actionable plan to immediately and continuously improve the financial health of

Rowboat Creative We have used the Profit First method to analyze your business, set financial targets

and to outline a method to achieve them.

​

What makes Profit First unique is that it is a behaviorally based cash management system. Instead of

regularly digging into financial reports and conducting frequent financial analysis, Profit First enables

you to instantly measure your financial health and take action by simply looking at your bank balance

periodically.

​

Utilizing this report will guide you through the implementation of Profit First, make sure that you remain

accountable to the quarterly profit goals, and help you adjust the profit (and other financial) goals going

forward.

​

Where you are now: Where we are taking you:

​

Details For Recommended Profit First Rollout

​

Total Revenue - It is common for business owners to focus aggressively on top line growth. From our

experience, entrepreneurs want to drive top line growth to increase the bottom line (profitability),

instead of just focusing on the bottom line itself. This often causes a trap of constantly increasing

revenue and increasing costs in parallel.

​

    Our recommendation: Drive profitability improvements as the priority over top line revenue    growth. Revenue growth will be a natural benefactor of improved profitability and focus.

​

Cost of Goods - Reducing the costs of materials and subcontractors, without compromising the quality

and/or performance, is a powerful way to increase the amount of Real Revenue and since it won’t

require more OpEx (Operating Expenses) that money typically goes directly to Profit and Owner Pay.

​

    Our recommendation: Thoroughly analyze all of your top costs such as garments and seek ways    to decrease these costs. Typically, an 80/20 (Pareto) principle applies to this category and can    be used to find costs to cut that will not affect the performance or quality of your offering.

​

Real Revenue - Your Real Revenue is the revenue your firm generates when cost of goods are excluded.

This number is used to represent the ‘true’ income of a company, and the cash flow it manages ‘above’

Real Revenue. No recommendation necessary.

Profit - Your historical profit in relation to your Real Revenue is in alignment although when subtracted

from your total owner’s pay, it is slightly lower overall than what we have found in fiscally healthy

companies experiencing similar Real Revenue.

​

    Our recommendation: Increase your Profit allocation to 15% of Real Revenue.

​

Owner Pay- Your historical Owner Pay is slightly higher than what we have found in fiscally healthy

companies experiencing similar Real Revenue. Some business owners elect to put more funds into

Profit and others into Owner Pay. Regardless, your combined historical Owner’s Pay in salary combined

with draws is slightly higher than we suggest if you plan to focus on the business profit.

​

    Our recommendation: Target your Profit allocation at 15% of Real Revenue as well as target    your total Owner’s Pay to 20% of Real Revenue over 6 quarters.

​

Tax - Your historical Tax allocation is substantially less than what we have found in fiscally healthy

companies experiencing similar Real Revenue. The Tax account is used to pay both corporate tax and

the income tax of owner’s. Without a Tax account, the owner’s income typically further has taxes

deducted from it. The Tax account allocates money to pay that tax liability.

​

    Our recommendation: Increase your Tax allocation quarterly, and in appropriate percentages, to    match the increase in Owner’s Pay. Any excess Tax allocations that are ultimately not required    would then be transferred to the Profit account.

​

OpEx - Your historical Operating Expenses are higher than what we have found in fiscally healthy

companies experiencing similar Real Revenue. This has directly resulted in a lower combined allocation

to Profit and Tax reserves.

​

    Our recommendation: Decrease your Operating Expenses in direct relation to the increase of    Profit and Tax allocations over upcoming quarters.

​

The concept and implementation of Profit First is simple. Sticking to it is the hard part. Our job is to

make sure you stick with Profit First, and to help you navigate the unique challenges that inevitably

present themselves.

​

Let us start with the easiest part first, the concept:

​

The Profit First Formula

The GAAP (Generally Accepted Accounting Principles) formula for determining a business’s profit is Sales

– Expenses = Profit. It is simple, logical, and clear. Unfortunately, it is a lie. The formula, while logically

accurate, does not account for human behavior. In the GAAP formula profit is a left over, a final

consideration, something that is hopefully a nice surprise at the end of the year. Alas, the profit is rarely

there and the business continues on its check to check survival.

​

                                      Sales – Expenses = Profit

​

                                      Sales – Profit = Expenses

​

With Profit First you to flip the formula to Sales – Profit = Expenses. Logically the math is the same, but

from the standpoint of the entrepreneur’s behavior it is radically different. With Profit First, you take a

predetermined percentage of profit from every sale first, and only the remainder is available for

expenses.

​

Parkinson’s Law

Author and historian C. Northcote Parkinson theorized that our demand for a resource increases to

meet the supply of it. That is why when we are given two weeks to do a project it takes two weeks, and

when we are given eight weeks to do the same project it takes eight weeks. That is why when given

$1,000 to complete our work we get it done with $1,000 and when given $10,000 to complete the same

work, it takes $10,000. Profit First makes Parkinson’s Law an asset. By taking profit first the money

available for expenses lessens, and we are forced to find ways to get the same things done for less

money.

​

A History of Success

Admittedly, Profit First is nothing new. It is the application of the time tested and world’s greatest

financial mechanism “pay yourself first” applied to entrepreneurship. Just as wealthy people know to

pay themselves first and then use the remainder for expenses, Profit First teaches us to take our profit

first and then use the remainder to run the business. The 401K retirement plan has been the greatest

savings mechanism in US history, because of this powerful “pay yourself first” premise. Profit First is

already proving to be the greatest profit generating mechanism in the history of business, because of

this same powerful principle. So, while Profit First is nothing new, it is totally unique. And it is truly

effective.

​

Bank Balance Accounting

Most entrepreneurs don’t have the time or gumption to read the different accounting statements

necessary to manage the financial aspect of their business. Theoretically you should review and

correlate your Income Statement, Balance Sheet and Cash Flow Statement monthly (or more

frequently), but few entrepreneurs do. Most resort to “bank balance accounting,” where we check our

bank balance every day and make financial decisions based upon what we see. Per Parkinson’s Law, we

consume what we see in our bank account. Profit First encourages the entrepreneur to continue “bank

balance accounting” by first allocating money to profit (and other accounts) so that the entrepreneur

sees the actual portion of deposits that are available for expenses, and they automatically adjust their

spending accordingly.

​

Don’t Change Habits, Leverage Them

Many entrepreneurs try to force themselves to become better at accounting and to become more

disciplined in their fiscal management by pure willpower. But just like a muscle, willpower can be

drained. And in a moment of financial stress or bigger than expected expenses the entrepreneur will

break their own fiscal rules and spend the money they have. The Profit First principle does not try to

change your habits (that is nearly impossible to do), Profit First works with your existing habits. By first

allocating money to different accounts, and then removing the temptation to “borrow” from yourself,

your business will become fiscally strong, and you will benefit from regular profit distributions.

​

Profit First Professionals and its affiliates are not liable for a success or failure of Profit First cash flow

methodology. Successful implementation and adherence to the Profit First methodology is solely                 dependent on the owner of the business implementing Profit First.

​

Hope you are well and it has been a pleasant week.

I wanted to shoot you a note as to the attahched payments that came through the

account .

We have Aeriz now as a sublease tenant for their merch warehousing. You will see

monthly payments $2k due on 1st of the month) for them coming through as ACH

I just wanted to clarify this as they also pay regular production / merch

invoices via ACH, however I usually see those and mark off the payments in

Printavo for the correct invoices.

$6000: Security deposit

Body Snippet: Hi Lucas, We've contacted your shop about migrating to Printavo's new embedded payment platform, but we haven't heard back from you. As of April 3rd, your current Stripe and/or Auth.net
Email RTF:
Hi Lucas,

​

We’ve contacted your shop about migrating to Printavo’s new embedded payment

platform, but we haven’t heard back from you.

​

As of April 3rd, your current Stripe and/or Auth.net payment automations will no

longer be supported.

​

This means you will not be able to accept payment in Printavo.

​

Sign up in just minutes and stay worry-free with our secure, fast

processing – including ACH (our most requested feature).

​

Sign Up Now

​

Get paid with Printavo!

​

Printavo's embedded payment platform is available now.

​

You get ACH payments, secure credit card payments, and unlimited support from

our team.

​

It takes just minutes to sign up.

​

Need more time?

​

If you need more time, are under contract, or have a unique situation, we’re

happy to work with you. But you have to act now. Just reply to this email.

​

Don't wait - apply by March 15th

​

90% of shops are approved instantly, but we've found that some businesses

require additional verification – and that can take up to 14 days.

​

Please apply by March 15th to beat the April 3rd deadline so you can keep

processing payments without any disruption.

​

Did we get this right?

​

This message is intended for US-based shops that use Stripe or Auth.net for

payment processing.

​

If you believe you have received this message in error, please reply immediately

or contact your Customer Success Manager (success@printavo.com) for additional

information.

​

Tell me more!

​

Read more info about embedded payments here.

​

Learn best practices and see it in action here.

​

You're receiving this message because your shop is located in the US and uses

Auth.net or Stripe to process payments. If you've already signed up for

Printavo's embedded payments or have contacted us about an extension, you can

disregard this message.

​

              227 W. Monroe St., #5200, Chicago, IL 60604

Hi there,

​

To bridge the gap in this situation, I recommend that you, Lucas, add a health

care reimbursement to your salary equal to Joe’s health care payments each pay

period so that the ending salary for each owner is equal. I see this in many of

Stephanie & Sheri: My apologies for the continued combative unrelated dialogue

for this thread. You are both aware of the ongoing struggles with the working

You have full access to all internal systems which provide sales reporting for

your review.

• To further speak on my vision for any current or future sales plans, the

immediate plan simply involves mitigating continued financial damages, as well

as client relationship damages you continue to cause Rowboat Creative. As I have

previously illustrated, as well as documented/brought to your attention which

received no response, your aggressive and hostile behavior has once again been

reported to me causing the loss of a growing client, as well as an immediate

need to refund over $8,000 due to an ill-advised unprofessional altercation with

a customer. This recent event comes just over 2.5 weeks after receiving another

documented report of your aggressive and hostile behavior threatening the

working client relationship of another fruitful contract decoration client. I

had been personally working on larger standing quotes with this client that were

ultimately sent to another facility resulting in loss of sales revenue. In my

continued due diligence for a sales role, which I have always maintained, the

entire industry is moving slower this year. There has been no intent to throttle

sales of any type, however as you will further read, there is a plethora of

concerns that certainly might have an impact on sales. Ultimately, my position

and view is that sales will always fluctuate as they have for 15+ years. Your

personally financial status or situation is by no means the responsibility of

Rowboat Creative to uphold. If you have found yourself in a situation wherein

Rowboat Creative can no longer support your lifestyle or financial obligations,

perhaps it might be best to consider a buy out or pursuit of another career.

Additionally, there is growing cause for concern that production deadlines are

no longer being met. There have been multiple occurrences of this in the last

week alone which ultimately causes client distrust for Rowboat’s ability and

responsibility. An order specifically presented to you for approval on timeline,

which you agreed to, still has not shipped in full which was for another large

client with a very firm event date. Whether it be myself, or a team of 20+ sales

representatives for the company, I do not currently hold 100% confidence in your

ability to currently maintain important deadlines and/or conduct yourself in a

professional manner to interact with current customers, prospective clients, or

any potential newly added sales representatives for Rowboat Creative. Working

diligently to close sales and prospective relationships should not be at risk of

damage due to unprofessional or irresponsible behavior.

In regards to my financial outlook, I have personally been responsible for

diligently handling / juggling both Accounts Payable, as well as Account

Receivable, in addition to all sales generation and potential new business,

amongst other things. Your unprofessional behavior, which ultimately resulted in

our corporate banking account closure, has caused an exceeding amount of clean

up, all of which has been done without your assistance. You have access to all

shared company email accounts and surely see the amount of correspondence I am

involved in on a daily basis to maintain all sides of finance. A shared document

was created to provide full transparency of all incoming and outgoing payments

that have/will be due which is fully maintained by me. You have been asked

repeatedly to assist in including anticipated payments or anything financial to

assist in budgeting both weekly and daily. You have refused. Today alone saw

your ill-advised and erratic decision to withdraw a large lump sum personal loan

to the business without discussion. I have no place to speak on why you needed

the loan repaid immediately in full, however in your constant demand of mutual

decisions, this rather large financial decision made and executed by you

erraticly is just another example of concern I carry.

• RE sales: While I continue all sales efforts with the same tenacity I always

have, (which resulted in a record revenue year for Rowboat in 2022), I am

unable to, in 100% confidence, look to onboard new business with the current

status of our working relationship and your continued combative behavior that

is, and has been, a very large liability to Rowboat Creative for quite some

time. As my previous email saw, I have requested a meeting between all parties

included to discuss the financial status and outlook from two other very

intelligent and substantial parts of our Rowboat Creative financial team. The

last scheduled meeting with Spark, which you showed up late for, saw more

instances of your combative and insulting behavior. I would hope that any future

meetings be handled more professionally and maintain discussion for only the

necessary topics at hand.

• RE no checks: This was a mutual decision made years ago as there were several

documented instances of check fraud wherein checks written to Rowboat Creative,

and delivered to 4200 W. Diversey Avenue, were being stolen and deposited

illegally. It was also a mutually decision to help mitigate lags in payment

being received to assist in cashflow. All orders are to be paid in full in

advance of production, with the exception of any NET term clients, which are

required to process terms payments via ACH. Lastly, the decision was also in

effort to remove your need to drive around depositing checks, causing

interruption for your more important day-to-day responsibilities. This mutual

agreement was made quite some time prior to the forced bank closure.

Lastly. short of things turning around drastically for the working relationship,

my right to pursue dissolution of Rowboat Creative is absolutely viable and in

consideration based on, but not limited to the above.

Thank you.

course of action should be that Joe processes an ACH transfer or wire from his

course of action should be that Joe processes an ACH transfer or wire from his

personal bank for the amount of $4004.92 into the corporate account for these

invoices. There are exceedingly large payments that need to be chiseled down so

every little bit helps. I have included the payment information again as a

footer.

​

I will not speak on Joe’s personal matters, however I will stand firm that

personal matters and/or financial situations are by no means the responsibility

of Rowboat Creative, as a corporation, to uphold. Should personal matters, on

either side, continue to be a source of damage to the financial health and

future of this company, I maintain that I will motion for dissolution of the

company or welcome formal conversation as to buyout options for either party.

​

Thank you.

Name: Spark-em-451
Subject: Updates, Financials, Agenda
Body Snippet: Hi L&J, I am sorry I couldn't get the full update to you on Friday as planned; I had something urgent and had to switch gears. I have been adding updates whenever I thought I was ready to send;
Email RTF:
Hi L&J,

​

I am sorry I couldn’t get the full update to you on Friday as planned; I had

something urgent and had to switch gears. I have been adding updates whenever I

thought I was ready to send; there was more to add! Thank you for sending the AP

& AR list, Lucas; that is super helpful; we are primarily aligned with that. I

spent a ton of time cleaning the books this morning, and you will see by the

attached reports we are pretty dialed in. I made some notes on your sheet where

we would have discrepancies.

​

Joe, in terms of depositing the cash as a distribution, I would advise you not

to do that. For starters, that is a slippery slope regarding tracking; it’s much

more straightforward to see all deposits go through the bank. But also, we are

looking to nail down a live cash budget; if you were to take revenue and

distribute 100% of it to yourself, there is no allocation remaining for anything

else; the material cost of that project, the labor, overhead, etc. If depositing

cash is prohibitive, do not accept cash. Apps can deposit checks on your phone;

better yet, this task should be delegated to a manager on-site so you can focus

on the more important stuff.

​

So that we may hit the ground running tomorrow for our meeting, I am putting

together a rough outline of agenda topics I would like to cover together,

supported by the attached reports.

​

o Profit First Implementation: We need to isolate the income account from all

expenses; once this is complete, I will move the money for you based on theallocations we discussed. This is your living, breathing budget; we want tokick this into gear asap.

o Setting up your Profit Sattelite Accounts for Shareholder Distributions

o Closing the Month- I will close the Month to ensure no errant payments or

invoices are brought over, creating additional clean-up work and expenses.

o Alternative payroll providers. I am not a fan of QBO payroll, so I was glad

to hear you were open to exploring new options. While Spark does notadminister payroll, we work with several other companies. One I think youwould like a lot is Gusto. Most of my screen printing clients work withthem. I have a partner program that allows you discounts, perks, and VIPservice using this link:<https://gusto.com/partners/invite/spark-business-consulting>

o Streamlining revenue and cost of goods reporting. I have worked to clean the

chart of accounts, products, revenue streams, and accompanying costaccounts. If the financials do not accurately represent sales by category,we are spinning our wheels and will never know the correct margins or salesnumbers.

o Cashflow is tight, and the payables are high; I think visibility on this

will help to keep everyone on the same page and develop a plan for reducingthis asap.

o Cost of Goods review

o Reimbursements and Due to Shareholder Account Details

o Airtable- can you please share this with me? Is the report I was going to

receive last Month? I have not seen this yet.

o Voiding invoices vs. Closing out with a discount.

​

Thanks so much! I am looking forward to covering a lot of ground tomorrow! If

you have anything, in particular, you would like to go over that I haven’t

mentioned here, please send it along so we won’t miss it.

​

Name: Spark-em-458
Subject: Re: Updates, Financials, Agenda
Body Snippet: Hi Stephanie, I just wanted to follow up with some points that I think would be beneficial to address: • Hoping we can leave the meeting with a productive and distinctive plan of action to begin
Email RTF:
Hi Stephanie,

I just wanted to follow up with some points that I think would be beneficial to

address:

• Hoping we can leave the meeting with a productive and distinctive plan of

action to begin mitigation of debt / cash flow issues

• I would like to address the reduction of owner salaries, if advisable, until

cash flow concerns are in a better place.

I anticipate very strong push back on this element and while I am sympathetic to

personal financial struggles, the company should not bear the brunt of monetary

responsibilities.

The increase in salaries were based on Sheri’s recommendation and 2022 numbers.

2023 trajectory and current financial health should be looked at to help

determine healthy and realistic salaries that the corporation can current

sustain.

• AR: I handle all AR related correspondence and have been productive in doing

so but this is also an element included in our Spark package I would love to get

in motion.

There is an outstanding balance for an order Joe handled back in August 2022

that still has a $3200 open balance. My suspicion is that there was an issue

with this order he does not want to tell me about. I have asked for close to a

full year now in trying to be proactive with cashflow only to be told stay out

of it. Not sure what to do anymore as every little bit helps.

• Sales goals: While I understand sales goals, you have seen the combative

nature surrounding this. I am really not sure where to go with goals as my focus

has been on damage control from his repeated behavior ultimately impacting

sales.

• Payroll: Another hot issue we will likely see resistance on. I do not feel

comfortable with how Joe processes payroll, let alone last weeks occurrence of

him just deciding to pay back a personal loan through payroll. I imagine this is

not proper protocol and that we also ended up paying a sizable additional

payroll tax burden for this. His resistance to letting anyone else handle

payroll is going to be because he will no longer be able to process draws

whenever he so pleases. An outside party handling payroll that Spark works

directly with will give better clarity of budgeting and cash flow forecast IMO.

• Spark handling Sales Tax processing moving forward. We are already paying for

this as part of our current package. This will allow for late payments fees to

hopefully no longer happe, as well as taking advantage of the early payment

discounts available.

• Draws: Again a topic I expect resistance on. I think it is crucial that a

protocol is established that no longer allows for draws to be dispersed without

discussion or financial advisement. I see the current cash flow issue being

heavily due in part to no protocol for draws.

• In regards to any legal discussion, I have been advised that we do not discuss

any legal matters or questions. Not only do I find this uncomfortable and

inappropriate to be addressed in your direction, Joe has been put on legal

notice to address any legal concerns or questions to my retained council.

• I saw that Joe chose to pay for the 3 orders (originally paid in cash) via his

own credit card through Printavo. While this ultimately gets the money back into

the RBC account, he neglected to charge himself credit processing fees for all

the orders which cost the company $160.20. While this battle is fruitless in the

midst of the larger issues, I see it once again as an example of Joe moving

forward with an ill-advised financial move both you and I provided a very

practical solution for. The cash he deposited in his personal account could have

been electronically transferred to the corporate account. I believe his

resistance is just another grounds for his tantrums relating to the bank

situation, in which he is oblivious to the larger issues cased by his behavior.

Lastly, it has been advised that we seek professional mediation immediately to

try and get the train back on course. Not only have I tried to proactively

reinforce the dire necessity of this, my attorneys have as well directly to Joe.

I would imagine you are in agreement that the partnership has become untenable

but I am left with very few options left ultimately that will result in legal

action against Joe, as well as dissolution of the company. I am not asking for

anything further than the hope that Joe might understand the sheer Rowboat is in

to longer exist which will be a heavy financial blow on all sides.

While I do anticipate this meeting being met with an abundance of resistance /

combativeness, I am hoping we are ultimately able to have a productive meeting.

I apologize in advance should things go off the rails and I appreciate your

professionalism in the midst of all current struggles.

Thank you Stephanie!

_______________________________

Lucas Guariglia

cell: 847.828.0944

office: 773.675.BOAT (2628)

CEO | Co-founder

​

Rowboat Creative

Hi Stephanie,

Thanks.

If she can pull financials for me that would be wonderful.

I am mostly curious if Spark is moving forward with sales tax processing.

There were quite a few elements we did not get to address in our meeting and

mostly looking for support on how to balance what is happening financially right

now. The credit card is nearly maxed and I am doing the nest I can with

providing payments to keep vendors happy, try to chisel down the cc, etc, along

with generating as much in sales as possible. However, we have payroll coming up

and I am unclear how best to proceed with juggling.

We are clearly at an impasse with the bank situation which effects what Spark

needs to do and I am scared to death each day that a large chunk I am not

expecting is going to come out of the account from Joe processing a draw via QBO

payroll.

I really don’t want to create any more issues than there are so any insight

would be helpful!

Thanks and enjoy your time away.

Name: Spark-em-468
Subject: Sales Tax
Body Snippet: Hi there! I hope you are both having a great week. I apologize for cutting this so close to the wire; typically, I would send this with plenty of lead time to review. I was out of the office earlier
Email RTF:
Hi there!

​

I hope you are both having a great week.

​

I apologize for cutting this so close to the wire; typically, I would send this

with plenty of lead time to review. I was out of the office earlier this week

and had a family emergency this morning.

​

Attached is a sales tax report from QBO that I verified against Printavo. To

clarify, I will adjust to match the tax amount received so that you comply with

what you have taken from your clients, as that is what you should pay back to

the state, but I see that tax-exempt customers are being charged for sales tax.

As we advance, you may want to ensure that you are not charging them sales tax

and save yourself a little legwork with the filing. Kindly review and let me

know if that sounds correct.

​

I will need a code to access the tax connect portal, or better yet; I will need

to be set up with an accountant’s account to log in moving forward. As a

temporary fix, you could add our Spark number for the second-factor

authorization to receive the code (781) 853-5247. Can you please confirm you can

assist?

​

Thank you!

​

                  Stephanie Morin                       Director of Business & Brand Development

​

                       Spark Business Consulting                       (781) 871-1003  |  [www.sparkbusinessconsulting.com](http://www.sparkbusinessconsulting.com)                       stephanie@sparkbusinessconsulting.com                       164 Washington St. Norwell, MA, 02061

Hi Steph!

Hope you are well. I am hoping you can share insight or how we can

collaboratively go about supporting the current financial status on things.

I have been working extremely hard with pushing sales, having to manage the

relationships with vendors for their payments, manage the credit card, staying

on top of clients that owe us money, trying to forecast out payments, trying to

forecast out payroll and other necessary payments such as sales tax, payroll

taxes etc, and I am just feeling like it is an uphill battle I need support on.

I do not receive any inclusion of potential payments coming up for payroll,

taxes, or even supply expenses to try to keep in consideration from Joe. There

has been a shared doc that has not been updated from him in over a month aside

from April 4 when he updated that he was withdrawing his loan to the business.

this.

Hi Steph,

necessary.

Transparently, I am not sure what to do any further. I am just very confused and

concerned how we are now in this position. We came off of last year which saw an

outrageous amount of draws then fueling Sheri’s insight to increase salaries.

There is nothing that can be done about last year at this point but I have

voiced needing to reduce salaries based on the reality of the situation and it

just feels like there is nothing I am able to offer without Joe perceiving it as

a personal attack or that I am throttling business.

If I am understanding things as you showed, we have 4 months until doors shut.

That means quite a bit in several different directions so do you feel a meeting

with all parties, including Sheri should take place?

On May 2, 2023, at 3:40 PM, Stephanie Morin <stephanie@sparkbusinessconsulting.com> wrote:

Hi Lucas!

​

I am sorry if that came off as super doom and gloom. You are not covering your output by combining your business’s

operating income/ loss with the current liabilities or cash that is not on the profit and loss. If you look at your

operational input/output, your cash burn rate is closer to 14-16 months. I am also factoring in paying down debts and

liabilities. So, you will not be locked up and shut down in four months, but if the contribution rate and margins do

not change, you will be taking on additional debt; that is the only way to fund a loss in the business. So, I advise

you to look at it thoroughly and proactively. We can review together, but unfortunately, this week is tight for me,

and I have small gaps of time available. I believe we have our monthly meeting scheduled for Tuesday. I can try to

bump that up to Monday. Let me know what you think and if that works. Thank you!

Hi Steph,

Thanks for the video. This clarifies but I think a meeting is going to be necessary.

​

Transparently, I am not sure what to do any further. I am just very confused and concerned how we are now in this

position. We came off of last year which saw an outrageous amount of draws then fueling Sheri’s insight to increase

salaries. There is nothing that can be done about last year at this point but I have voiced needing to reduce salaries

based on the reality of the situation and it just feels like there is nothing I am able to offer without Joe

perceiving it as a personal attack or that I am throttling business.

​

If I am understanding things as you showed, we have 4 months until doors shut. That means quite a bit in several

different directions so do you feel a meeting with all parties, including Sheri should take place?

Name: Spark-em-486
Subject: Change of Meeting Format Today
Body Snippet: Hi Lucas, Hi Joe, I hope this email finds you both well. I apologize for the short notice, but I am currently dealing with a severe migraine and would like to request a change in our meeting format for
Email RTF:
Hi Lucas, Hi Joe,

I hope this email finds you both well. I apologize for the short notice, but I

am currently dealing with a severe migraine and would like to request a change

in our meeting format for today.

Instead of a Zoom call, I would like to propose that we communicate via email. I

understand this may not be the most ideal way to connect, but given that I

haven't improved with medication, I believe that this would be the best option

for me to still be able to cover the key topics we need to discuss.

Please find below a bulleted list of items and action points that I would like

to review with you. I hope that this will suffice for now and allow us to still

make progress on our agenda. Please let me know your priorities as well.

* Reviewing margins in effort to streamline and reduce cost

* Transparency for what your daily, weekly, monthly goals are based on

contribution margin and average overhead

* What to do when you do not hit these goals, and what to do when you do

* For canceled orders that occurred in Q1, is there inventory on hand? Do you

have an approximate value to that? Are you able to use any of this forfuture orders to offset cogs?

* Reviewing overhead expenses in detail to cut costs, I believe there are

duplicate subscriptions that you could cut back on

* Reviewing open invoices, AR lead time for cash flow

* Reviewing unpaid bills and liabilities for cash flow

I will forward an updated current detailed report with notes that support the

above items. Thank you for your understanding and flexibility. I know this is

not ideal, but I am looking forward to hearing back from you on the reporting

and items above and reconnecting as soon as possible.

Best,

Link: themeData

Hi Stephanie,

Here are some additional bullet points to address:

• Addressing cash burn rate I touched on this in my video and reporting. On average you are losing $7,000 a week.

Anything you can do to stop the bleed right now is helpful. I sent a detailed expense report. Please review to see what

can drop off. Addtionally, the cost margin is too high for 2023. Jan and Feb were tough. March and April look better.

Were can you add charges for your services, cover costs, increase fees? Were is the leak? I do not want you to take a

loan out to cover operating cost, so you need to scale them back.

• Address Lucas loan payback -I would like to execute a plan to have personal loans reimbursed prior to any future

draws. I will no longer be able to provide personal loans to the business at this time. Confirming this is the 25K owed

to you?

• Addressing reality of necessary wage reductions / layoffs if necessary based on business financial health Absolutely,

the wages are the biggest expenses and your biggest asset. I have your total wages less the shareholder's at 32% that is

relatively healthy. This excludes outside services but includes production labor.

• Re-addressing owner salary based on 2023 revenue vs 2022. Should Sheri review this? Would like to avoid this but this

should be considered. I have proposed a temporary reduction, your 2023 revenue doesn't support it, while looking to add

quarterly profit distributions to make you whole but only when the business can support it.

• Mitigating credit card debt Paying this out of the profit distribution holding all additional owner expenses and

reducing debt. Ultimately it puts money in your pocket by reduces interest debt.

• Niky’s embroidery is still owed $12,418.85. This vendor ultimately increased pricing which resulted in overpayments

being provided to him.I have been asked to speak directly to the owner, and have on several occasions, whom feels he is

due what he is owed. A resolution has not been reached as RRBC does not have the current cash flow to support any larger

payments to this vendor at this time. Thank you.

• Plan for support on AR + AP Let's discuss in detail. I can reach out clients on behalf of you. I can advise on AP

payment plans.

• INV 701082 was originally paid in full and now showing another open balance. Joe can you please address this as I

believe the change occurred after the order was rebuilt I assume.

• INV 701181 was originally paid in full and now showing another open balance. Joe can you please address this as I

believe the change occurred after the order was rebuilt I assume.

• INV 701221 was originally paid in full and now showing another open balance. Joe can you please address this as I

believe the change occurred after the order was rebuilt I assume.

• Need a better way of forecasting upcoming payments, payroll, sales tax, etc. I operate in the “WORKING ACCOUNTING

LEDGER” daily that has been shared again but this has become very time consuming in addition to my other roles. I would

like to operate out of a ledger that is from QBO which I work very hard to maintain and is real time. If I can export

reporting to you each on a specific date weekly, you can add to this anything that is forecasted.

• We are expecting payments this week which are always recorded in the “WORKING ACCOUNTING LEDGER” as I am made aware of

them to help with cashflow forecast. Excellent! We can create a weekly burn spreadsheet from the actual cashflows from

QBO adding in what you know will be coming in and out that I don't yet. I hope that is helpful. Please let me know.

Thank you.

Body Snippet: Good morning Joe. To clarify, my title is Chief Executive Officer of the company, and while we all wear many hats my continued focused roles as of late have been sales, new business outreach, marketing
Email RTF:
Good morning Joe.

To clarify, my title is Chief Executive Officer of the company, and while we all

wear many hats my continued focused roles as of late have been sales, new

business outreach, marketing (for which I am not provided necessary elements),

all general info email fielding, all accounting email fielding, all A/R, all

A/P, all payments budgeting, all sourcing, activation staffing + scheduling,

vendor relations, as well as all due diligence involved in seeking potential

dissolution or formal resignation from the current intolerable partnership.

You have been included on quite a few occasions citing the financial concerns,

concerns of your repeated combative behavior, concerns of your personal

financial responsibilities in relation to the Corporation, and your adamant

resistance to professional insight and recommendations as to how to proactively

turn the current status of Rowboat Creative around.

I have no obligation to include you in conversations or meetings. When I have

attempted, you have chosen to refuse the meeting and/or show up late causing an

uncomfortable meeting for everyone with your erratic temperament. Phone calls

are not recorded as that seems to only be an ongoing practice for you which

could see legal ramifications if proper protocol is not followed.

My position, as I have made clear on several occasions, is the absolute

inability to work with your current erratic, combative, and potentially damaging

behavior. I have been instructed to keep communication at a minimum which allows

me to conduct uninterrupted business during a pivotal state. I have continued to

do my absolute best and will continue to do so in light of an uncertain future

for Rowboat Creative. At this point, I would like to focus on mitigating debt,

conversations of reciprocal buyout, or dissolution.

From a sales standpoint, I am in agreement with the points Stephanie has

included as to increasing pricing, reducing expenses, and the consideration of

reduced wages.

I think you might find it helpful to consult quite a few industry

periodicals/articles that have been circulating for months as to the state of

the industry, as well as the general downturns similar industries have been

experiencing/bracing for. I have had numerous conversations with company owners

over the last weeks who are experiencing the same, conducting layoffs, and

taking pay cuts. I have included a recent article I received from a colleague

this morning.

You constant attacks as to my efforts are nothing more than distraction. While

your efforts on the two recent sales you seem to be completing are appreciated,

the inclusion of discounts (one being very sizable) is again of concern coming

off of several recommendations from Stephanie to reduce discounts. It is

unfortunate we are able to move forward productively with Sparks efforts.

Should you feel that any of my efforts are in legal question, you have been

provided my attorney’s contact information in both email and hard form.

@Stepahnie: I will respond to your follow up questions in chain shortly. I

wanted to once again update the shared docs with current values.

Thank you.
